entry.title: FreeBSD
entry.content:
FreeBSD  1

My pet project. Just random notes on playing around with an old school open-source Unix-like operating system. Sections of this relate to my Prometheus project.

  • Install FreeBSD 14.0
    • Server specs
    • Install packages
    • Install VirtualBox guest additions
    • Fix the prompt
    • Fix display resolution
    • Add a nic
  • Install Prometheus node_exporter
  • SSHD
  • Add a HDD
  • Install Sendmail
  • Using email
    • Install dovecot
  • Install Apache
  • Commands
  • vi
  • Links

Install FreeBSD 14.0

This installs a basic setup in VirtualBox with:
  • UI
  • VirtualBox guest additions so you can copy/paste.
  • Firefox browser.
  • 2 nics (1 internal, 1 NAT for internet).
  • Bash installed to fix command prompt to show user@host.

Server specs

  • Name: bsd.
  • 1 CPU.
  • 1 GB memory works OK, add more if needed.
  • 16 GB disk.
  • 2 nics (1 during install, 2nd added later).

Use defaults for most of the install. At the end, create a user called ant and make sure you add it to the wheel group.

Install packages

Login as ant then su to root and run these commands:

pkg update

pkg install -y nano

pkg install -y xorg

pgk install -y xfce

pkg install -y slim slim-themes

pkg install -y firefox

These commands write to /etc/rc.conf.

sysrc dbus_enable="YES"

sysrc hald_enable="YES"

sysrc slim_enable="YES"

sysrc sound_load="YES"

sysrc snd_hda_load="YES"

vi /home/ant/.xinitrc

add exec startxfce4 and save it.

reboot

Install VirtualBox guest additions

Login as ant then su to root and run these commands:

Note: You don't need to specify a version, it'll know what to do:

pkg install -y virtualbox-ose-additions

pw group mod wheel -m ant

vi /etc/rc.conf

Make sure these are present, top 2 are probably there:

  • dbus_enable="YES"
  • hald_enable="YES"
  • vboxguest_enable="YES"
  • vboxservice_enable="YES"
No idea what this does but do it:

echo ". /usr/local/etc/xdg/xfce4/xinitrc" > ~/.xinitrc

Fix the prompt

When you start a terminal the prompt has only $. I think this is the default Bourne shell. Let's install the Bash shell to fix that prompt.

Login as ant then su to root and run these commands:

pkg search bash

pkg install bash

pkg install bash-completion # dunno what this does.

chsh -s /usr/local/bin/bash ant

chsh -s bash # dunno what this does.

Confirm bash is default shell for ant. Use any of these commands:

getent passwd ant

grep ant /etc/passwd

finger ant

Make sure you're in /home/ant.

vi .bashrc

Add this, exactly as written. Don't change anything or you'll get an error:

[[ $PS1 && -f /usr/local/share/bash-completion/bash_completion.sh ]] && \
. /usr/local/share/bash-completion/bash_completion.sh

Logout and login again and open a terminal.

The prompt should show ant@bsd.

Fix display resolution

Unresolved: I think this is a VirtualBox problem, not the OS. We are tied to using the VMSVGA graphics controller which only has 3 resolutions. The notes below are a start and we may fix it one day.

You don't need root for this.

If you go to Applications > Settings > Display you only have these resolutions available:

  • 1024 x 768
  • 800 x 600
  • 640 x 480
Shutdown the VM and go to VM > Settings > Display. Change Graphics Controller to VboxVGA (VBoxSVGA works too). You can enable 3D acceleration but the settings don't stick. You'll see an Invalid settings detected message below, it doesn't seem to matter.

Start the VM then go to Applications > Settings > Display again. Notice you have more resolutions now. We still have a problem though, none of these fits well on my screen so we need to set a custom resolution.

Open a terminal and type xrandr. Pay attention to these, we'll need them:

  • Resolutions supported by your video card.
  • Refresh rate (60).
  • Min & max ranges, as long as you keep within this you can set whatever resolution you want. 
  • Display name i.e. VGA-0.
Let's try 1342 x 784 as it's a good fit for my monitor.

We need to calculate the modeline string for xrandr so we pass the resolution and refresh rate to the gtf tool, 60 is the refresh rate:

gtf 1342 784 60

Copy everything after Modeline then run this to add the new display mode (your output might be different):

xrandr --newmode "1344x784_60.00"  85.75  1344 1408 1552 1760  784 785 788 812  -HSync +Vsync

Add the new mode to the display you want to apply. Note VGA-0:

xrandr --addmode VGA-0 "1344x784_60.00"

This will apply the new mode or you can do it in the UI:

xrandr --output VGA-0 --mode "1344x784_60.00"

Now just do Adjust Window Size in VirtualBox and you're all set.

This doesn't survive a reboot, trying to fix here:

pkg install autorandr

only /usr/local/bin/easy_install-3.10 script has been installed

  since Python 3.10 is not the default Python version.

autorandr --save work


Add a nic

A few assumptions:

  • You have a user called ant configured.
  • Only 1 nic configured called em0 in FreeBSD, set to NAT in VirtualBox.

Login as ant then su to root and run these commands:

View current state:

ifconfig

There will be a lo0 which is the loopback.

em0 should have an IP like 10.0.2.15 assigned by VirtualBox.

Shutdown the VM (you need to do it from UI) and add a 2nd nic set to Internal Network.

Start the VM.

Login as ant then su to root and run ifconfig again. You should have an em1 nic now.

Set the IP address:

ifconfig em1 inet 1.1.1.3/8

Make the change persist across reboots. This writes the info to /etc/rc.conf:

sysrc ifconfig_em1="inet 1.1.1.3 netmask 255.0.0.0"

Note: To set a nic to dhcp run this:

sysrc ifconfig_em0="DHCP"

Restart netif for the changes to kick in.

service netif restart

👏

Install Prometheus node_exporter

A few assumptions:

  • You have a user called ant configured.
  • Prometheus server configured. Steps here.

Login as ant then su to root and run these commands:

pkg search node_exporter

At writing the version was 1.6.1_7. Check it's good then run:

pkg install node_exporter

service node_exporter status

It's not running, let's start it:

service node_exporter status

Set it to start at system startup.

sysrc node_exporter_enable="YES"

👏

SSHD

By default the SSHD service is installed so you can putty and WinSCP to it using the ant login. Here's some setup notes anyway.

Make sure this is in vi /etc/rc.conf:

sshd_enable="YES"

By default root can't ssh. Do this to enable it:

vi /etc/ssh/sshd_config

Change PermitRootLogin yes and save it.

service sshd restart

👏

Add a HDD

I wanted to do some disk space tests (alerts and such) so needed to add a 2nd disk in VirtualBox. Let's do it...

Shutdown the VM and go to Settings > Storage.

You probably have Controller: IDE with a HDD and optical disk. Click on the image of a green plus sign on top of a hdd (hover over it and says Adds hard disk.).

Click Create and add a VDI (VirtualBox Disk Image) type of 2 gb in size and click Finish.

Choose it from the Not Attached list (it might show as compname_1.vdi) and will be attached to  Controller: IDE. Hit OK and start it up.

Login as ant then su to root and run these commands:

Identify the newly added disk. It's probably ada1 and should be 2 gb in size:

geom disk list

I got these next steps from here.

gpart create -s GPT ada1

gpart add -t freebsd-ufs -a 1M ada1

gpart show ada1

newfs -U /dev/ada1p1

mkdir /newdisk

Add this to /etc/fstab, I just used a single tab to separate them.

/dev/ada1p1    /newdisk    ufs    rw    2    2

mount /newdisk

👏

Install sendmail

This was part of my Prometheus project because I wanted to get email notifications. The only problem is I'm not exactly sure what I did, so here's some rough notes. If you do a rebuild, fix up the notes as needed.

I started with this article and tried to get the Gmail bit working but gave up and decided just to get mail going internally, which is all I wanted anyway. I set /etc/dma/dma.conf back to default (commented out relevant sections) and deleted the file /etc/dma/auth.conf the article said to create. So now we're clean..ish?

I did have to install Sendmail. Before doing that I ran service sendmail status and it returned something (can't remember) that looked like it was installed which is weird. Anyway I ran this:

pkg install sendmail

And version 8.18.1 was installed cleanly. You need to read the output after the install. The only bit I did was run this:

cd /usr/local/etc/mail && cp mailer.conf.sendmail mailer.conf

Create a file called /etc/mail/access and add this. It allows localhost and the Prometheus server to connect:

Connect:[127.0.0.1]
Connect:[1.1.1.2}

Run these to auto start sendmail services:

sysrc sendmail_enable="YES"
sysrc sendmail_msp_queue_enable="YES"

Start sendmail (it will start sendmail_msp_queue too):

service sendmail start

Check services are running:

service sendmail status

Try and connect from the Prometheus server:

Test-NetConnection -ComputerName bsd1 -Port 25 -InformationLevel "Detailed"

Hopefully it's working.

You can see mail logs with this:

cat /var/log/maillog

Using email

Let's check our email. On bsd1 make sure you're on a ant@bsd1 terminal. You can use the in-built mail program but it's pretty scabby so let's install mutt:

pkg install mutt

You might get this prompt:

/home/ant/Mail does not exist. Create it? ([yes]/no): 

Say yes.

Run it by typing mutt.

One thing I noticed when you're in this program, you can see new messages by pressing a key (arrow up/down) which is handy. Mail doesn't do that.

You might have messages in there already. Here's some basic navigation:

  • [enter] to read an email, [i] to go back to inbox.
  • [d] to delete email.
  • [q] to exit (this is when it purges deleted emails).

Let's try send an email from the Prometheus server.

On bsd1 run C:\Build\alertmanager\email_alert.ps1. For some reason it takes a long time, problem for another day. Did you get an email? If so, let's hook up Prometheus to send emails when an alert triggers.

Install dovecot

Update 9/9/2024 - I never got this working so left it. If you want to pick it up, start from the end of the section.

This enables IMAP/POP.

pkg install dovecot

Run this

cp -R /usr/local/etc/dovecot/example-config/* /usr/local/etc/dovecot

this too

sysrc dovecot_enable="YES"

Try and start and you'll get an error:

service dovecot start

Starting dovecot.
doveconf: Fatal: Error in configuration file /usr/local/etc/dovecot/conf.d/10-ssl.conf line 12: ssl_cert: Can't open file /etc/ssl/certs/dovecot.pem: No such file or directory

We've got a cert problem.

vi /usr/local/share/examples/dovecot/dovecot-openssl.cnf

Update these bits:

# Locality Name (eg. city)
L=Melbourne

# Common Name (*.example.com is also possible)
CN=lab.com

# E-mail contact
emailAddress=ant@bsd1

find / -name mkcert.sh

It's in /usr/local/share/examples/dovecot. Run this command. Note the bash at the beginning, we're telling the shell to run it with bash not sh:

bash /usr/local/share/examples/dovecot/mkcert.sh

Another error:

/etc/ssl/private directory doesn't exist

Let's make it then:

mkdir /etc/ssl/private

Try again:

bash /usr/local/share/examples/dovecot/mkcert.sh

Another error:

Can't open "dovecot-openssl.cnf" for reading, No such file or directory
002061BA34310000:error:80000002:system library:BIO_new_file:No such file or directory:/usr/src/crypto/openssl/crypto/bio/bss_file.c:67:calling fopen(dovecot-openssl.cnf, r)
002061BA34310000:error:10000080:BIO routines:BIO_new_file:no such file:/usr/src/crypto/openssl/crypto/bio/bss_file.c:75:

cd /usr/local/share/examples/dovecot

bash mkcert.sh

Something worked! Remember these lines from /usr/local/etc/dovecot/conf.d/10-ssl.conf?

ssl_cert = </etc/ssl/certs/dovecot.pem
ssl_key = </etc/ssl/private/dovecot.pem

Let's check they exist now:

ls /etc/ssl/certs/dovecot.pem
ls /etc/ssl/private/dovecot.pem

They do! Let's try start it again:

service dovecot start

Start here...

Install Apache

This is so I can some stuff in Prometheus/Grafana.

Install it:

pkg install apache24

Auto start apache:

sysrc apache24_enable="YES"

Start it:

service apache24 start

You might get a warning about being unable to "determine the server's fully qualified domain name". It doesn't seem to matter but if you want to get rid of it add ServerName bsd1.lab.com to /usr/local/etc/apache24/httpd.conf

Restart apache:

service apache24 restart

Now go to http://localhost and you should get a page with It works!  on it. 👏

Commands

Date & time

Get current date and time:

date 

Format is date yymmddhhMM.ss

date 2409031713

Disks

IDE HDD names start with ad – /dev/ad0 first IDE hard disk, /dev/ad1 second hard disk.
SATA/SSD HDD names start with ad – /dev/ada, /dev/sdb.
SCSI HDD names start with da – /dev/da*
IDE CDROM/RW/DVD names starts with acd – /dev/acd*
SCSI CDROM/RW/DVD names starts with cd – /dev/cd*
NVM Express disk driver/NVM Express core driver names starts with nvd or nvme – /dev/nvd0

Get all HDD, CDROM, SSDs (there's a few ways to do this):

grep -E 'da[0-9]|cd[0-9]' /var/run/dmesg.boot

geom disk list

camcontrol devlist

diskinfo -v disk_name

This is a weird one:

sh -c '. /usr/share/bsdconfig/device.subr;f_device_menu "" "" "" DISK'

Get current partition info:

gpart show

Get partition size:

df

Human readable:

df -h

Files & folders

Copy file in same folder:

cp a.txt b.txt

Delete file:

rm a.txt

Find file:

find path -name file

Make folder:

mkdir /etc/ssl/private

Remove folder and contents:

rm -r /usr/local/etc/dovecot

grep

Find enabled service by name:

service -e | grep sshd

Find the word tcp in a file and sort:

grep tcp /etc/services | sort

ls

Basic folder list:

ls

Show more info in tab format:

ls -l

Misc.

Logout of root after su:

CTRL + D

Packages

View packages:

pkg view

Find package by name:

pkg info | grep thund

Install:

pkg install sendmail

Remove:

pkg remove sendmail

Services

Control services:

service name start | stop | restart | status

Show services that are enabled:

service -e

Install service. These write to /etc/rc.conf.

sysrc sendmail="YES"

Sorting

You can put | sort on the end of most commands:

service -e | sort

Shutdown & reboot

Shutdown and power off:

poweroff

shutdown -h now

Reboot:

reboot

Allow user ant to shutdown/reboot system:

pw group mod operator -m ant

pw group show operator

System info

View hostname:

hostname

Change hostname (and persist across reboots):

sysrc hostname="bsd.lab.com"

Get OS version:

freebsd-version

uname -mrs

vi

Insert

ESC - Out of insert mode
i - Insert mode

Save

:q! - Quit don't save
:wq - Quit and save

Delete

dd or ndd Delete n lines
dw - Delete word
D - Delete to end of line
x - Delete character

Search

/ string - search forward
? string - search backward
n - find next

Undo

u - Undo last change
U - Undo all changes on line

Links

  • FreeBSD Handbook
  • Install with XFCE desktop and apps
  • Install with XFCE and VBox guest additions
  • Fresh ports

entry.title: Croissant
entry.content:
Makes 8. Takes 2 days. 🔒

  • General info
  • Ingredients
  • Day 1
    • Make dough
    • Make butter block
  • Day 2
    • 1st fold (3 lock-in)
    • 2nd fold (offset book fold)
    • 3rd fold (simple fold)
    • Cut triangles
    • Final shaping
    • Proofing
    • Baking
  • Notes

General info

  • Butter temperature for lamination should be 14-18 C.
  • Western Star or Woolies brand butter is fine (need 82% butter fat minimum)
  • Flour should have 11-11.5% protein (Mine is 12%).
  • Salt gives strength to gluten, provides yeast control and flavour.
  • Milk powder enhances flavour and relaxes gluten.
  • Butter adds extensibility and is like a lubricant for gluten.
  • I usually use milk to glaze. If using egg don't get it in corners as it can affect rise.
  • Avoid Lurpak butter, it's not as nice.

Ingredients

This will be 60% hydration.

  • Water - 150 gm
  • Yeast - 5 gm
  • White flour - 250 gm
  • Milk powder - 5 gm
  • Salt - 5 gm
  • Caster sugar - 25 gm
  • Unsalted butter (dough) - 50 gm
  • Unsalted butter (block) - 175 gm

Day 1

Kit

  • 2.4 ltr bowl.
  • Usual bits.

Make dough

  1. Room temp the butter.
  2. Add all dry ingredients (including yeast) to bowl and mix.
  3. Warm liquid to 35 C.
  4. Add liquid to bowl and mix.
  5. On bench, knead for ~10 mins then work butter in.
  6. Shape into ball and put in bowl.
  7. Cover and rest 6-8 hours, it doesn't really matter.
  8. Shape into a ball.
  9. Spray water in freezer bag, add dough and fridge overnight.

Make butter block

This video is a good reminder on technique.
  1. The butter needs to be softened or it will split the paper. 14 C is fine.
  2. Fold baking paper into 16 cm x 16 cm square.
  3. Put butter tower in middle and press with hand to spread about 10 mm thick. You mMight want to use baking/butter paper so hand stays clean.
  4. Fold up the paper. Use the rolling pin to gently press down and spread butter. Go easy or it will split the paper. Take your time with this bit. Slow wins the race.
  5. Gently flatten into square then fridge overnight.

Day 2

Takes ~7 hours, start as early as possible.

If it's cold, the first thing to do is kick off the humidicrib as it takes a while to heat up, set it to 28 C.

Kit

  • Big knife, sharpen it.
  • Rolling pin.
  • Freezer bag.
  • Cake tin and pizza tin.
  • Usual bits.

1st fold (3 lock-in)

  1. Take butter out of fridge and peel back all of the baking paper. It's a nightmare doing this when it's warm. Careful not to split it.
  2. Stick temp gauge in and wait till it gets to 14 C. If it's too cold it splits.
  3. Flour bench.
  4. Roll dough into rectangle twice as big as butter.
  5. Put butter on top of dough like so:








2nd fold (offset book fold)

  1. Need to wing this a bit.
  2. Roll with the seam to 4 mm.
  3. Cut off ends.
  4. Fold in ~1/3, place strips next to it, fold long end in to meet edges then fold whole thing over again. Avoid putting cutoffs on the edge, put them in the middle. 
  5. Cut sides to release tension.
  6. Rotate dough 90 degrees.
  7. Flatten to ~15 mm.
  8. Cover with freezer bag, in freezer 15 mins.

3rd fold (simple fold)

  1. Take out of fridge and roll in the same direction as before to ~5 mm.
  2. Cut off ends. Fold in 1/3 then fold over other 1/3.
  3. Cut sides to release tension.
  4. Rotate dough 90 degrees.
  5. Flatten to ~15 mm (you should be able to fit on a tray).
  6. Cover with freezer bag, in freezer 15 mins.

Cut triangles

  1. Flour bench.
  2. Roll in same direction 30 x 40 cm ~ 4 mm thick.
  3. Cut triangles, 10 cm at base, should get 8 (see pic below).
  4. Cover with freezer bag, in freezer 15 mins.






Final shaping

  1. Grease cake tin and pizza tray.
  2. For each croissant:
    1. Brush off excess flour.
    2. Stretch out the base.
    3. Small cut at the the bottom.
    4. Roll into croissant and put on tray (4 on each tray). Don't roll it tight or they'll split.

    Proofing

    Proofing temperature is best ~28 C. Any warmer and the butter can melt.
    1. Humidicrib should be close to 28 C now.
    2. Rest for 4 hours.
    3. Do wobble test.

    Baking

    1. Pre-heat oven 200 C for 20 mins.
    2. Remove side bit from cake tin.
    3. Boil kettle and glaze with milk.
    4. Bake with steam 1 min @ 200 C then 20 mins @ 180 C. Keep an eye on it toward end.

    Links

    • Richard Bertinet
    • Scott Megee
    • Benny's 1
    • Benny's 2

entry.title: Prometheus
entry.content:
Some notes on messing around Prometheus and Grafana.

  • Commands
  • Queries
  • Links

Servers

  • 1 x DC:
    • Name: DC1.lab.com.
    • IP: 1.1.1.1/8.
    • 2016 OS.
    • 2 GB memory.
    • IIS installed, default website running on port 80.
    • Node_exporter installed.
  • 1 x member server:
    • Name: PRM.lab.com.
    • IP: 1.1.1.2/1.
    • 2016 OS.
    • 8 GB memory.
    • Domain joined.
    • Prometheus, Blackbox_Exporter, Grafana, node_exporter installed.
    • Required files and folder paths. Get them from my GitHub:
      • C:\Build\alertmanager\alert_rules.yml
      • C:\Build\alertmanager\email.yml
      • C:\Build\alertmanager\email_alert.ps1
      • C:\Build\blackbox\monitor_website.yml
      • C:\Build\Prometheus\prometheus.yml
  • 1 x FreeBSD server: (optional, how-to here.)
    • Name: bsd1.
    • IP: 1.1.1.3.
    • FreeBSD 14.
    • 2 GB memory.
    • Apache, Sendmail installed.
    • Node_exporter installed.

DNS records

Add these A records for name res:
  • test.lab.com - 1.1.1.1
  • bsd1.lab.com - 1.1.1.3

Install Prometheus on Windows

Download the zip file from their website. You don't install anything, just run the executable.

The first thing you need to do it setup a prometheus.yml file. I have a test one here.

Extract the zip file and prometheus.yml to C:\Build.

Open PowerShell and run:

C:\Build\Prometheus\prometheus.exe --config.file=C:\build\Prometheus\prometheus.yml

Congratulations, Prometheus is running! 👏

Navigate the UI

Open a browser and go to http://server_or_IP:9090/.

Click on Status > Targets. Most likely everything is red except Prometheus Server. This is because of the config in prometheus.yml.

Let's fix some of that red!

Install windows_exporter agent

The agent for *nix OSs is called the node_exporter. For some reason, getting the Widows agent is a nightmare. As of 29/8/2024 it's not listed here. It's available on GitHub here. Scroll down to Assets and download the latest msi file.

Run the msi on both servers. I need to update this but I think it automatically installs as a service. It's called windows_exporter, yes nice and lowercase and ugly.

Run this to see if the port is listening:

Get-NetTCPConnection | ? {$_.LocalPort -eq "9182"}

Notice one is the local port and the other is the connection from the Prometheus server.

Go back to the Prometheus UI and refresh, click show more on Windows exporters. State should be showing green and UP.

Congratulations, you're monitoring Windows servers! 👏

There's a lot more to check out with this. Doco here.

Blackbox Exporter

Download the blackbox_exporter for Windows and unzip it on PRM.lab.com. Notice there's a default blackbox.yml, we won't use that. Download monitor_website.yml and to the blackbox folder then open it to take a look. The only bit we care about is the line http_2xx_example. Open C:\Build\Prometheus\prometheus.yml and notice the line module: [http_2xx_example], this needs to match with the module listed in monitor_website.yml.

Open the Prometheus UI and go to Status > Targets. Notice the targets blackbox and blackbox_exporter are red. Now run this command:

C:\Build\blackbox\blackbox_exporter.exe --config.file C:\Build\blackbox\monitor_website.yml

Wait a minute then refresh the Prometheus UI and you'll see blackbox and blackbox_exporter state is showing green. As I discovered in website testing below, this is kind of misleading.

Go to http://localhost:9115/, you can do some cool stuff here like look at probe results.

Let's do some tests

For icmp and website tests I downloaded a Grafana dashboard called Website monitoring. You can see some of the queries they used to build the dashboards.

Stop windows_exporter agent

We kind of saw this above but I want to do it again to highlight some interesting quirks.

This simulates a broken agent not communicating with the Prometheus server - just like SCOM grey agents.

  1. Open the Prometheus UI and go to Status > Targets.
  2. Stop the windows_exporter agent on any server.
  3. Refresh the UI. This behaves as you'd expect. State goes to red on the DC1.lab.com endpoint.
  4. Start the agent then refresh the UI again, it'll go green.
Yay, this works as expected. 👏

Stop blackbox_exporter process

Kill the blackbox_exporter process in the PowerShell session. Refresh the Prometheus UI. You'll see blackbox and blackbox_exporter state is red. If you run this command in Prometheus or Grafana you get no data returned:

probe_http_status_code

So if the blackbox_exporter isn't running, everything looks down. 🤯

Start blackbox_exporter again and make sure everything is green.

Stop a website

This is where things get interesting. Run this command in Prometheus:

probe_http_status_code

Notice http://prometheus.io is returning 0 and http://test.lab.com/ is returning 200. Why isn't http://prometheus.io showing down in Status > Targets?

Stop the http://test.lab.com/ website on DC.lab.com

The same thing happens. This is really odd. It's like health in Status > Targets for websites is more about the port check being up and running as opposed to the result returned.

Ping

This has the same behaviour as websites. Go to Prometheus UI > Status > Targets and click on blackbox-ping, you'll see they are showing green, but if you run this command it's showing dc1.lab.com green and 1.1.1.10 red.

probe_success{job="blackbox-ping"}

Alert manager

Let's get some alerts going.

There's 2 parts to this. Part 1 is creating rules that will generate alerts in Prometheus that can be viewed by clicking on Alerts in the UI. You can also see alert rules at Status > Rules. Part 2 is sending alerts to Alert Manager which can do a lot of funky stuff.

Part 1 is already done. If you look at the prometheus.yml file, you see this bit:

rule_files:
    - "C:\\Build\\alertmanager\\alert_rules.yml"

The backslashes are escape characters.

And if you look at C:\Build\alertmanager\alert_rules.yml, you'll see there's a rule called my_websites with this probe. Note it has been truncated:

probe_http_status_code == 0

Go to DC1.lab.com and stop the default website, then go to Alerts in the UI and refresh. You might catch it changing to State=PENDING. Refresh again and it'll be State=FIRING.

Start the website again. After a minutes refresh Alerts again and you'll see it's gone back to green.

So this is pretty cool. We're getting alerts, they reset to healthy when resolved, but we're not routing them anywhere useful. Theoretically you could use this UI to manage alerts, but we need something better! For this bit to work you need sendmail working on your FreeBSD server.

On the Prometheus server, run this:

C:\Build\alertmanager\alertmanager.exe --config.file C:\Build\alertmanager\email.yml

Go to http://localhost:9093.

Stop the website again and wait a few minutes. Check Prometheus to see if the alert fired then check mutt to see if you got an email. If you did it looks like this:

Date: Mon, 09 Sep 2024 09:34:04 +1000
From: ant@lab.com
To: ant@bsd1
Subject: [FIRING:1] website_gone_to_heaven (http://test.lab.com/ blackbox page)

It's a html email so I've removed the rest of the message.

There you go, we can get email notifications now 👏

Commands

This good to check files are OK to load.

C:\build\Prometheus\promtool.exe check config C:\build\Prometheus\prometheus.yml

Queries

Up examples

Get offline Windows instances"

up{job="Windows_exporters"}==0

Probe results:

probe_success{job="blackbox-ping"} # just get icmp.

probe_success # get all

CPU perf, all comps.

Note: I had a comp with 2 processors and it showed both of them in the chart.

rate(windows_cpu_processor_utility_total[30s]) / rate(windows_cpu_processor_rtc_total[30s])

CPU perf, 1 comp:

rate(windows_cpu_processor_utility_total{instance="DC1.lab.com:9182"}[30s]) / rate(windows_cpu_processor_rtc_total{instance="DC1.lab.com:9182"}[30s])

Possible good disk thing.

windows_logical_disk_free_bytes {volume="C:"} / 1e+9

FreeBSD disk info:

node_filesystem_avail_bytes{mountpoint="/"} / 1e+9

Links

  • Overview
  • Windows exporter
  • Intro to PromQL
  • prometheus.exporter.windows
  • Setup web monitoring
  • Grafana Website monitoring dashboard
  • Alerting rules - helped with alert labels.

entry.title: Grafana
entry.content:
This is a continuation to my Prometheus project. There's a lot to learn, as always the best way is to just start.

I installed Grafana Enterprise on PRM.lab.com. It was pretty simple.

Go to Connections > Data sources and add the prometheus data source. You should only need to add http://localhost:9090 to Connection.

Go to Alerting > Alert rules. Notice down the bottom it has C:\Build\alertmanager\alert_rules.yml listed with my two alerts.

Click on Dashboards and import the Dashboard_1 from GitHub. You can paste in the .json (easier) or upload the file.

If you simulate an alert they will appear here and Alerting > Alert rules, pretty cool seeing as we didn't do much.

Links

  • Visualizations

entry.title: Beer
entry.content:
• Harvest yeast
  • Mixology
  • Bottling
  • Brew log
  • Store bought

Notes & reminders

  • To buy:
    • Can opener; Wiltshire Super can is good, Culinare MagiCan shit.
    • Get IPA/Bootmake PA/Amber ale. They all use light dry malt, need 2-3 boxes.
  • Coopers recipe instructions website.
  • Coopers products website.
  • Use the can opener vertically. 
  • Some recipes need cooler fermentation temps.
  • Put yeast in fridge when you get home.
  • Get ABV: Coopers math ABV = (OG - FG) / 7.46 + 0.5 or calculator here.
  • It's 1 scoop Oxyclean to 3L water.
  • It's 1.5 ml StarSan to 1L water.
  • When taking gravity reading:
    • Pour 30 ml and discard it, then fill to top.
    • Take from bottom of the curve (meniscus).
  • When using tap, loosen lid to avoid suck back.
  • In summer, put a wet towel around FV. Put in freezer for 30 mins if super hot.
  • Pry off bottles:
    • Sail & Anchor.
    • John Boston.
    • James Squire.
  • The tap should look like this. The lever is on the short end. Attach to FV then push tap down into it to avoid finger shred:

Harvest yeast

Takes ~10 days total so prepare accordingly.

Vid here.

  • By beer and fridge it for a week to let yeast to settle.
  • Mix 60 gm light dry malt (Big W have it) with 600 gm water.
  • On Friday, pour beer into jug but leave about 2 cm in bottle. Jug is your swill beer.
  • Swirl the yeast and pour into bottle. Shake it over a few days.
  • Pour whole thing into wort.

Mixology

To figure out water calcs/volume use the scale spreadsheet.

Day 1

Prepare top-up water

  1. Rinse and sanitise the 4 L container and fill to 5 cm from top with filtered water.
  2. If it's hot put it in the fridge for cooling.

Day 2

Takes ~2 hours.

The goal here is to do a few things at the same time:

  • Soften the can.
  • Add water to FV.
  • Mixing sugar, extract and water at right temp/volume.

Clean up / prep

The 3 pots used are:
  • spag pot and lid - can softening.
  • small pot - 5 L - mixing.
  • large - 19 L - draining.

  1. Get everything from garage.
  2. Give all pots a quick rinse.
    1. Put metal tap on large pot.
    2. Add 1 scoop Oxyclean to large pot and 1.5 L cold water.
    3. Boil 1.5 L water and add to large  pot. Mix with big spoon.
    4. Add 1.5 ml StarSan and 1 L water to jug.
    5. Cut off 2 squares of glad wrap and put in jug.
    6. Remove label from can.
    7. Put can in pot and cover with tap water.
    8. Kick of stove heat.
    9. Go outside. Clean/rinse/sanitise everything, including temp gauge.
    10. Can-soften water should be boiling. Lower in with a fork and cover with lid. It will be ~50 C when we use it.

    Mixology

    • Fill the draining pot from the tap, when nearly full take a temp reading.
    • Use the calculator to figure out:
      • how much FV water you need.
      • how much top-up water you need.
      • do you need to warm top-up water?
      • how will can temps affect temperature?
    • Once you figure that out:
      • Fill FV as needed.
      • Heat top-up water if needed.
      • Add extract and sugar as needed.
      • Fill with top-up water.
      • Mix well then add yeast.
      • Done.

    Bottling

    Cleaning

    1. Bring out bottles and clean/sanitise first so you have more space to work in. Once racked bring out FV to settle.
    2. Put 1.5 L in kettle and boil it.
    3. Add 1 scoop Oxyclean and 2.5 L cold water to big pot. (need 4 L to submerge bottles)
    4. Clean and rinse everything.
    5. Add 1.5 ml StarSan and 1L water to bottling pot.
    6. Put 2 bottles in small pot and fill with tap water (for rinsing).
    7. Work with 2 bottles at a time and do this:
      1. Submerge and scrub.
      2. Rinse clean water.
      3. Sanitise and rack. Should get 24 done in ~15 mins.

    Filling

    1. Tip all water into jug and small pot to use later for cleaning.
    2. Flip big pot and put FV on top.
    3. Take a sample.
    4. Boil small amount of water in kettle.
    5. When using tap, loosen lid to avoid suck back.
    6. Assemble bottling wand. Pour water from kettle on the end of the adapter thingy, it helps putting on tap.
    7. As in picture below, fill 6 at a time.
    8. Add carb drop to each.
    9. Cap each then rack. Should get all done in ~30 mins.

    Store bought

    🍺🍺🍺
    • John Boston - Crisp lager, dry hopped
    • John Boston - Coastal XPA
    • Mountain Goat - Very Enjoyable Beer
    🍺🍺
    • Byron Bay Brewery Premium Lager
    • Fixation Obsession IPA
    • Hofler rein lager light
    • John Boston Pale ale
    • Mountain Goat steam ale
    • Mythos Hellenic beer
    • Sail & Anchor pale ale
    • Stubbie Refreshing Ale
    • Tona lager Nicaragua
    • Yarra valley Dortmund style lager
    🍺
    • James Squire Shackles lager
    • Wakachangi lager

entry.title: Roti
entry.content:
Vid here.

These are good, still testing. Makes 6.

Kit

  • 2 small fry pans

Ingredients

They should be ~86 gm each.

  • 309 gm flour
  • 168 gm water
  • 9 gm salt
  • 9 gm milk powder (to soften dough)
  • 24 gm melted ghee (in dough)
  • 40 gm melted ghee (for lubing)

Method

  1. Warm water and melt dough ghee (1 min on high).
  2. Add flour, salt and milk powder to bowl and mix.
  3. Add water and melted ghee and mix.
  4. Knead for 5 mins or until smooth.
  5. Leave 2 hours or overnight.
  6. Divide and roll into ball, rest 30 mins.
  7. Melt lubing ghee and begin the skinning:
    • Oil hands and bench, push with palm into a flat circle.
    • Rolling pin to ~25 cm.
    • Commence the flapping technique.
    • Stretch out to a square.
    • Lift it at the top and lower it down folding as you go.
  8. Slap-the-snake to lengthen. Flatten one end with your palm.
  9. Roll it up and tuck in the tail.
  10. Put on bench/plate and put some ghee over top.
  11. Rest 2 hours. The dough needs to relax. 2 hours worked great, can probably reduce.
  12. Heat pan(s) on medium for a few mins. Don't oil them.
  13. Roll ball out to ~20 cm. Not too thin.
  14. Bake medium heat 4 mins. Use the small fry pans on the big burners, just don't crank them.
  15. Remove from pan, add knob of butter to each and spread around.

Notes

entry.title: Pasta
entry.content:
Vid here. Aim for 55-57% hydration.

Kit

  • Green lid bowl - reuse for baguettes.
  • Fork.
  • Tbsp.

Ingredients

This is perfect for Friday night spag:

  • 320 gm flour.
  • 3 eggs (~55 gm each without shell).
  • Oil - 14 gm (1 Tbsp).
  • Salt - 6 gm (1 tsp).

Method

New method - I think this can work, do next time:
  1. Room temp the eggs a few hours before.
  2. Crack eggs in bowl then work out flour.
  3. Add oil and salt to bowl and stir with fork.
  4. Add flour and slowly and mix.
  5. Add water/flour as needed.
  6. Knead for 10 mins until smooth. It will spring back when pushed when it's done.
  7. Put dough in bowl then fridge it. You can pull out at roll time. Use within 24 hours.
  8. Roll out method (takes ~30 mins). Keep flouring dough to avoid sticking:
    • Cut into 4 pieces.
    • Set dial to 7, roll 2-3 times flipping each time.
    • Fold edges into centre then roll few more times.
    • Set dial to 3, roll 2-3 times flipping each time.
    • Set dial to 1, roll roll 2-3 times flipping each time.
    • Cut in half then shred as you like.
    • Grab the clump. Toss around in flour.
    • Repeat.
  9. Cook 3 mins total or in boiling salted water? Need to work this out. Next time try 3 mins total, do taste test.

entry.title: Remove stuck VM and disk
entry.content:
I had a problem in VirtualBox where I wanted to create a new VM but the name was already taken. I stupidly delete the VM in the UI but the disk file remained. I had to run these to clean it out:

First get the UUID of the VM, UB is the VM name.

C:\Program Files\Oracle\VirtualBox>VBoxManage.exe showvminfo UB

Scroll up and get the UUID info and enter it into this command:

C:\Program Files\Oracle\VirtualBox>VBoxManage.exe unregistervm d9e6f731-b62a-499d-99cf-29380f29bc94

You should be able to create the VM now.

entry.title: Pizza
entry.content:
Makes 3 pizza bases. Takes 2 days. Sauce optional. 🔒

Kit

  • Blue lid bowl.
  • Usual bits.

Poolish

  • 100 gm water.
  • 100gm flour.
  • 1 gm yeast (1/4 tsp).

Dough

  • 182 gm water.
  • 276 gm flour.
  • 6 gm salt.

Day 1 Method

  1. Make poolish and leave overnight.

Day 2 Method

  1. Warm 182 gm water to ~35 C and add to bowl.
  2. Add 276 gm flour and salt, mix until no dry spots.
  3. Cover and rest 1 hour @ 21 C.
  4. Do 10 bowl slaps.
  5. Cover and rest 1 hour @ 21 C.
  6. Do 10 bowl slaps.
  7. Cover and rest 1 hour @ 21 C.
  8. Put in fridge.
  9. Use within 3 days.
Temp guidelines:
  • 19 C - take out 1.5 hours before cooking.
  • 25 C - take out 1 hour max before cooking.
  • +30 C - take out 45 mins max before cooking.

Sauce

Ingredients

  • 1 can tomatoes.
  • 1/2 onion.
  • Tbsp garlic.
  • Oil.
  • 1 tsp Basil.
  • 1 tsp Oregano.
  • 1/2 tsp sugar.
  • 1/2 tsp salt.
  • Pepper.

Method

  • Cook onions in oil.
  • Add tomatoes, garlic, basil and oregano. Lid on for 5 mins.
  • Add sugar, salt and pepper to taste.
  • Keep on heat until it looks good then let cool.

entry.title: Focaccia
entry.content:
Makes 1 focaccia, On a hot day this takes ~4 hours. 🔒

For more flavour, do steps 1-4 then leave out overnight. Start early if doing same day.

I use the humidicrib and pizza pan in winter. If using other pans remember big tray=thinner / small tray=thicker, don't use the thin black one).

You need baking paper for rectangle pans, not round pizza tray.

Kit

  • Usual silver bowl.
  • Usual bits.

Poolish

  • 100 gm water.
  • 100 gm flour.
  • 1 gm yeast (1/4 tsp).

Dough

  • 300 gm water.
  • 400 gm flour.
  • 2 gm yeast (1/2 tsp).
  • 10 gm salt.

Day 1 Method

  1. Make poolish and leave overnight.

Day 2 Method

  1. Warm 300 gm water to 35 C and add to bowl.
  2. Add 1/2 tsp yeast and dissolve.
  3. Add 400 gm flour and salt and mix.
  4. Cover and rest until doubled (2 hours).
  5. Do some stretch-n-fold like pizza.
  6. Cover and rest until doubled. (2 hours. Skip if short on time).
  7. Choose your pan.
    • Round pizza tray
      • Butter it up.
    • Rectangle trays.
      • Line it with baking paper.
  8. Give it some slap-n-fold.
  9. Shape into ball and put on tray.
  10. Cover and rest until doubled (2 hours).
  11. Use baking stone and pre-heat oven.
  12. Toward end, oil dough well and stretch and dimple.
  13. Sprinkle well with salt. Don't be shy.
  14. Bake with steam 16 mins (lighter) or 18 mins (darker) @ 250 C.
  15. Take off tray and put on baking stone halfway through.

Toppings

Add 5 mins before putting in oven.

Tomato, garlic, basil, parmesan

  • 1 full size tomato, 1 garlic clove, oil, salt, pepper, dried basil
  • Quarter tomato the rip apart with fingers in small silver bowl.
  • Add other ingredients and mix.
  • Oil up focaccia as usual then add large tomato chunks.
  • Add brine.
  • Grate parmesan over top.
  • Add salt as usual.

Notes

25/8/2024

Did half tomato topping, turned out really good. Not soggy. Could put on earlier to get some seep in.

17/8/2024

Buttered the round pizza tray and it didn't stick too bad. You need to flip it because the dough seeps through the holes and anchors itself to the tray, scrape it off and it'll pop out.

I don't like the white soft underbelly, next time at half way point you could try removing tray and putting on baking stone.

Also try some toppings.

entry.title: Splunk
entry.content:
This sums up Splunk...

"Exploratory Data Analysis: Spelunking with Splunk
What if you don’t know anything about the data? Get creative and explore. You can do a search for "*" to retrieve all events and then learn about them: look at some events, extract some interesting looking fields, get a top of that field, see how the events are broken up, perhaps derive some new fields based on other fields, cluster your results, see how one field varies with another field, and so on."

Study progress 🤓

Do some searching on food.csv. You need to re-import again.

Current reading

C:/Data/Splunk/exploring-splunk.pdf

Pg 45. Do some where searches for IP addresses in "main" index.

Chapter 4 is great to learn searches.

C:/Data/Splunk/Splunk-9.2.2-SearchTutorial.pdf

Pg 50. Start Example 1: Search without a subsearch

    Searches

    Getting started, some basics

    Remember: The 3 fields returned in all searches are host, search, searchtype.

    New line: Shift + Enter.

    Comment stuff out ```like this.```

    The Splunk test data is great but there's lots of it. I wanted to learn searches with a smaller data set so I created a file in Notepad called food.csv containing this:

    time,type,name,quantity,price
    20:35:31 24/07/2024,Junk,Burger,3,$17.99
    20:35:32 24/07/2024,Healthy,Apples,15,$12.00
    20:35:33 24/07/2024,Junk,Chips,14,$7.65
    20:35:34 24/07/2024,Healthy,Oranges,45,$90.43
    20:35:35 24/07/2024,Junk,Mars bar,6,$6.60
    20:35:36 24/07/2024,Healthy,Watermelon,1,$4.50
    20:35:37 24/07/2024,Junk,Doritos,8,$34.89
    20:35:38 24/07/2024,Healthy,Pumpkin,1,$4.55
    20:35:39 24/07/2024,Junk,Twisties,3,$8.22
    20:35:40 24/07/2024,Healthy,Broccoli,6,$36.99
    20:46:15 24/07/2024,Junk,Crunchie,6,$8.64
    21:14:48 24/07/2024,Healthy,Apples,7,$5.60
    21:14:49 24/07/2024,Healthy,Apples,3,$2.40

    You can run this command to generate timestamps:

    1..10 | % {Get-Date -format "HH:mm:ss dd/MM/yyyy";sleep 1}

    I added a data input that constantly monitored the file so I could add new events.

    Let's learn some shizzle...

    Show all events (default)

    index="ant-food-index-csv"

    Count events

    Above command gets this by default but good to know.

    index="ant-food-index-csv"
    | stats count

    Sort by quantity ascending

    index="ant-food-index-csv"
    | sort quantity

    Sort by quantity descending

    index="ant-food-index-csv"
    | sort - quantity

    Search for 2 fields and quantity greater than 10

    index="ant-food-index-csv" type="healthy" name=apples 
    | where quantity > 10

    This does the same:

    index="ant-food-index-csv" healthy apples 
    | where quantity > 10

    Count how many times food items were purchased and sort by name

    This will generate a Statistics view so you can create graphs in Visualization.

    index="ant-food-index-csv" 
    | top name 
    | sort name 

    Placeholder.




    Show the number of events in your indexes and their sizes in MB and bytes

    | eventcount summarize=false report_size=true index=* | eval size_MB = round(size_bytes/1024/1024,2)

    Get all events from all sources

    This is a good place to start. It gets all events from all indexes. If you then look at sources and sourcetypes you can start narrowing down.

    index=*

    Show all productName count in pie chart

    This shows the count of all products sold in a pie chart. Not sure rare is best way. 

    sourcetype=access_* status=200 action=purchase| rare limit=20  productName

    Subsearch good explanation

    The search command, like all commands, can be used as a subsearch - a search whose results are used as an argument to another search command. Subsearches are enclosed in square brackets.

    For example, to find all syslog events from the user that had the last login error, use the following command:

    sourcetype=syslog [search login error | return user]

    Here, a search for events having the terms login and error is performed, returning the first user value found, say bob, followed by a search for sourcetype=syslog user=bob.

    Subsearch example

    This is a good query to examine and play around with. It's from pg 50 in the Search Tutorial. It starts at Example 1: Search without a subsearch but this is from Example 2 that uses a subsearch to achieve the same result running 1 query.

    The query in [] is searched first. The output of that is sent to the "outer" query. Note the renamed columns, particularly the clientip column.

    sourcetype=access_* status=200 action=purchase 
        [ search sourcetype=access_* status=200 action=purchase 
        | top limit=1 clientip 
        | table clientip] 
    | stats count as "Total Purchased", distinct_count(productId) as "Total Products", values(productId) as "Product IDs" by clientip 
    | rename clientip AS "VIP Customer"

    Get count of events

    index="antwineventlogs" | stats count

    Get top x purchasers

    By default top returns count and percent fields.

    sourcetype=access_* status=200 action=purchase | top clientip limit=1

    Using table command discards count and percent fields:

    sourcetype=access_* status=200 action=purchase | top clientip limit=1 | table clientip

    Add them back like this:

    sourcetype=access_* status=200 action=purchase | top limit=1 clientip | table clientip, count, percent

    See sources in an index

    This can be improved. You need to click on source in Selected Fields to see them.

    source=* index="antwineventlogs"

    Search for multiple events with any of these terms

    This will return terms error, fail, failure, failed, failing, or severe, in the events that also mention buttercupgames.

    buttercupgames (error OR fail* OR severe)

    Returns number of events in indexes

    Notice the comment. You can either specify the index or use * to get all.

    | eventcount summarize=false ```index=_audit index=main``` index=*

    | eventcount summarize=false index=*

    Sorting

    By default searches are sorted by the _time field, with most recent at top (is this ascending or descending?).

    Sort by time oldest first

    I think this is OK. 0 means return all events, don't stop at 10,000 which is default. This is a weird one, normally to sort descending you'd prefix the field with "-".

    index=main 
    | sort 0 _time

    Where

    These return the same result but where is slower and searches more events. Don't know why yet.

    Using Where:

    index="main" 
    | where like (clientip, "87.194.216.5%")

    Not using Where:

    index="main" clientip="87.194.216.51"

    Random stuff

    Delete indexes

    Web UI, go to Settings > Indexes and delete it.

    Write 10 unique timestamps to add to csv file.

    1..10 | % {Get-Date -format "HH:mm:ss dd/MM/yyyy";sleep 1}

    Interesting Fields are fields that appear in at least 20% of the events

    Field names are case sensitive, but field values are not.

    The Statistics and Visualization tabs populate when you run a search with transforming commands such as stats, top, chart, and so on. 

    When evaluating Boolean expressions, precedence is given to terms inside parentheses. NOT clauses are evaluated before OR clauses. AND clauses have the lowest precedence.

    The AND operator is implied when you type in multiple keywords.

    Sources and Sourcetypes

    A source is the name of the file, stream, or other input from which an event originates—for example, /var/log/messages or UDP:514. Sources are classified into sourcetypes, which may be well-known, such as access_combined (web server logs) or can be created on the fly by Splunk when it sees a source with data and formatting it hasn’t seen before. Events with the same sourcetype can come from different sources—events from the file /var/log/messages and from a syslog input on udp:514 can both have sourcetype=linux_syslog. 

    Entering an asterisk (*) in the search bar retrieves all the data in your default indexes - This might explain why data from my custom indexes don't get returned.

    When you first run a search the Selected Fields list contains the default fields host, source, and sourcetype. These default fields appear in every event.

    Interesting Fields are fields that appear in at least 20% of the events.

    punct=punctuation.

    Search Processing Language (SPL)

    Create AntSplunk event log source to test events

    Note: This new source goes in the Application log.

    Also note: When you add an event log it only gets events from the time you added it, it doesn't get all past events.

    New-EventLog -LogName Application -Source "AntSplunk" 

    Write-EventLog -LogName Application -Source AntSplunk -EventId 1 -EntryType Information -Message "Information event - things are great." -Category 0

    Write-EventLog -LogName Application -Source AntSplunk -EventId 3 -EntryType Error -Message "Error event - things are bad." -Category 0

    Write-EventLog -LogName Application -Source AntSplunk -EventId 2 -EntryType Warning -Message "Warning event - things are dodgy." -Category 0

    Monitor custom Event Log

    By default Splunk only sees certain event logs. If you make a custom log it won't see it so you need to add it manually. This worked on my Splunk instance, I think it's the same on a forwarder or heavy forwarder.

    • Add the new log and source.
    New-EventLog -LogName SplunkLog -Source "NewSplunk"
    • Add an event.
    Write-EventLog -LogName SplunkLog -Source SplunkSource -EventId 3 -EntryType Error -Message "Error event - things are bad." -Category 0
    • Edit C:\Program Files\Splunk\etc\system\local\inputs.conf and add this.

    [WinEventLog://SplunkLog]
    checkpointInterval = 5
    current_only = 0
    disabled = 0
    index = antwineventlogs
    start_from = oldest
    • Restart Splunk.
    Restart-Service -Name Splunkd

    Universal Forwarder

    Notes on setting up UF on Windows server.

    I had some trouble disabling the collection of mem, cpu, network, disk stats. During the UF install I selected all options then changed them to select Application log only. When the install completed, it was collecting event from the app log, mem, cpu, network, disk which I didn't want.

    Figuring out how to disable that was "fun" so I ended up removing and installing the UF again, and just selected Application log. Once it connected only App log events were coming in.

    This was great for debugging. Run it on problem forwarder. It shows the config and file locations it loads.

    C:\Program Files\Splunk\bin\splunk.exe cmd btool inputs list --debug

    These links might help:

    Blog to stop forwarding data
    Enable disk collection

    Anyhoo...it turns out the inputs.conf file is in quite a few locations and googling it returns confusing answers, so let's do some testing.

    After UF I had this file:

    C:\Program Files\SplunkUniversalForwarder\etc\apps\SplunkUniversalForwarder\local\inputs.conf

    Containing this:

    [WinEventLog://Application]checkpointInterval = 5
    current_only = 0
    disabled = 0
    start_from = oldest

    I'm going to assume collecting App log events is working because of this.

    I also had this file:

    C:\Program Files\SplunkUniversalForwarder\etc\system\default\inputs.conf

    Containing this:

    # Version 9.2.2
    # DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE!
    # Changes to default files will be lost on update and are difficult to
    # manage and support.
    #
    # Please make any changes to system defaults by overriding them in
    # apps or $SPLUNK_HOME/etc/system/local
    # (See "Configuration file precedence" in the web documentation).
    #
    # To override a specific setting, copy the name of the stanza and
    # setting to the file where you wish to override it.
    #
    # This file contains possible attributes and values you can use to
    # configure inputs, distributed inputs and file system monitoring.
    <REMOVED FOR BREVITY...>

    The rest of the file contains a lot of default-looking config. As it says, you don't make edits here, but in, wait for it, $SPLUNK_HOME/etc/system/local, which as it turns out, doesn't exist. Nice!

    So now you're thinking "my stuff is working" but the inputs.conf file is in C:\Program Files\SplunkUniversalForwarder\etc\system\default\.

    Let's test adding something to the file and see what happens.

    I add this:

    Configuring Windows event logs for Enterprise Security use

    Good link here:

    Configuring Windows event logs for Enterprise Security use

    Links

    Useful stuff I've found along the way. 
    • The Search Manual - good. Also here C:/Data/Splunk/Splunk-9.2.2-Search.pdf
    • Alert Manual - check out later.
    • Exploring Splunk - good
    • Search Tutorial - good. Also here C:/Data/Splunk/Splunk-9.2.2-SearchTutorial.pdf
    • Getting data in
    • Cheat sheet - also here C:\Data\Splunk\splunk-quick-reference-guide.pdf
    • Universal Forwarder
    • Admin Manual
    • Splunk main components
    • Free courses
    • Splunk Tutorial for Beginners
    • Good cheat sheet

The Elastic Stack is comprised of:
