  • Kibana
  • Beats
  • Logstash 
This is known as the the ELK Stack.

This looks good.

Overview of Elastic components.

entry.title: Azure Monitor
entry.content:
Start with this overview, it's awesome and a great refresher.

On this page

  • Level 1 - Basic Monitoring
  • Level 2 - Windows Azure Diagnostics extension
  • Questions
  • Random Notes
  • AzMon Pic

Links

  • Training: Monitor Azure VMs with Azure Monitor

There are many parts to Azure Monitor. This blog attempts to explain what each of them do starting from basic (no agent installed) to advanced (agent installed).

Official Azure Monitor documentation here.

Build a VM

If you need to build a VM for testing that performs well, this is recommended (and cheap):
  • OS: I've used Win11 and Server 2019
  • Size: Standard B1ms (1 vcpu, 2 GiB memory)
  • Location: Australia East (Zone 1)
DO NOT use Standard HDD that costs about $9 it's dog slow.

VM monitoring - getting started

So you don't max out Az credits, only collect what you need for testing then delete/disable it.

I'll use VM monitoring as a starting point as it's the most logical example.

There are four layers to VM monitoring. Explained here. I don't know if they match up, but I'll go through each thing I find in Azure that looks like it's for VM monitoring.

Basic Monitoring

When you build a VM, some stuff is monitored by default.

In short:

"With an Azure virtual machine you get host CPU, disk and up/down state of your VMs out of the box. Enabling additional monitoring capabilities provides insights into the performance and dependencies for your virtual machines."

  1. Go to Your_VM > Overview.
  2. Scroll down to the tabs called Properties, Monitoring, Capabilities... and click on Monitoring.
  3. Under Performance and utilization you'll see some basic metrics collected.
  4. Click on Show more metrics. Notice we have availability, cpu, disk, network metrics.
  5. Below that is Guest OS metrics. Notice how it's blank and we need to Configure VM Insights.
  6. Below that is Additional Azure Monitor tools. We'll look at that later.
  7. Scroll up and click on See all Metrics. It will bounce you to Your_VM > Monitoring > Metrics where you can see all the metrics it collects.
  8. Check out the Metric Namespace and Metric drop-downs. Notice under Metric Namespace, the only option is Virtual Machine Host.
You can see there's some interesting stuff there. Let's create a high CPU alert just to show what can be done without installing any agents.

Create action group

  1. Go to Monitor > Alerts and click on Action group.
  2. Click Create and use these setting for each tab:
    • Basics:
      • Subscription: Your subscription.
      • Resource group: Your resource group.
      • Region: Global.
      • Action group name: TestTeam.
      • Display name: Test Team.
    • Notifications:
      • Name: Email to Ant.
      • Use an email account.
      • Yes to Enable the common alert schema.
    • Actions:
      • Do nothing.
    • Tags:
      • Do nothing.
    • Review + create:
      • Click Create.
  3. Confirm the new action group is there.

Create alert rule

  1. Go to Monitor > Alerts and click on Alert rules.
  2. Click Create and use these setting for each tab:
    • Scope:
      • Click Select scope and type in your VM name and select it. It should show the VM name under Resource and the subscription name and resource group under Heirarchy.
    • Condition:
      • Signal name: Percentage CPU.
      • Threshold: Static.
      • Aggregaton type: Average.
      • Operator: Greater than.
      • Threshold value: 80.
      • Check every: 1 minute.
      • Lookback period: 1 minute.
    • Actions:
      • Select the action group from above.
    • Details:
      • Subscription: Populated already.
      • Resource group: Populated already.
      • Severity: 0 - Critical.
      • Alert rule name: High CPU alert
      • Alert rule description: The CPU is going crazy bro.
    • Tags: Blank
    • Review + create:
      • Click Create.

Test the alert

  1. Login to your VM and download the CpuStres tool. You should be able to do it with the installed IE version.
  2. Delete all the time series listed and click on the green plus sign.
  3. Right-click it and change the Activity Level to Maximum (100%).
  4. Start the thread (green triangle).
  5. You can open perfmon or taskmgr to see the CPU spike.
  6. Confirm you got the email notification.
  7. Go to Monitor > Metrics and search for your VM.
  8. Use these settings:
    • Metric Namespace: Virtual Machine Host.
    • Metric: Percentage CPU.
    • Change the time range (top right) to Last hour.
  9. Go to Monitor > Alerts. Notice we have an alert. Click on the alert name.
  10. Here you can change the user response and add a comment. I don't think you can just add a comment, it has to be when changing the user response.
  11. Go to the VM and pause the thread. Make sure the CPU comes down.
  12. Go to Monitor > Alerts. After about 5 minutes click Refresh and the alert will automatically close because it's under the threshold.
  13. You will also get an email saying it's resolved.

Summary

This worked well. I also created a server down alert and it worked. The auto-close alert is awesome. If you look at the Details tab in the alert rule you'll see there's an Automatically resolve alerts check-box. I'd like to do more testing to see what other alerts that works on. Initial impression is it's pretty good but limited if you want to dig into the OS or get logs, so let's move up to the next one...

Windows Azure Diagnostics extension

So you don't max out Az credits, only collect what you need for testing then delete/disable it.

    Now we're moving into agent territory. The WAD extension is a VM extension (type of agent?) but I think it's considered legacy. It's important to understand the differences between agents and where data is sent.

    In short:

    "Azure Diagnostics extension is an agent in Azure Monitor that collects monitoring data from the guest operating system of Azure compute resources including virtual machines. You can collect metrics and logs from the guest operating system that runs as part of a virtual machine. you can write metrics directly to the Azure Monitor metrics store, where standard platform metrics are already collected. By storing them in this location, you can access the same actions that are available for platform metrics. Actions include near real-time alerting, charting, routing, access from the REST API, and more."

    The Azure Diagnostics extension for both Windows and Linux always collects data into an Azure Storage account.

    Create storage account

    Before you start, you need to create a storage account. If you go to Your_VM > Monitoring > Diagnostic settings, you'll see Enable guest-level monitoring isn't available because there's no account under the Diagnostics storage account drop-down. This is where the diagnostic data is sent (read up on that). Let's set it up...
    1. In  the portal search for Storage accounts and select it under Services.
    2. Click Create Storage Account.
    3. Put in your details. Example:
      • Subscription: Already populated.
      • Resource group: Already populated.
      • Storage account name: lowercaseletterandnumbersonly
      • Region: Already populated.
      • Performance: Standard.
      • Redundancy: Locally-redundant storage (LRS).
    4. I went through each tab but didn't change anything.
    5. Click Create.

    Enable monitoring

    1. Go to Your_VM > Monitoring > Diagnostic settings.
    2. Select the new storage account from the drop-down and click Enable guest-level monitoring.
    3. It will install the WAD extension, then bounce you to a page with various tabs. I'll discuss each one below, except Event Tracing and Crash Dumps.
    4. If you click through the tabs you can see stuff is already being collected.
    A few things happen now:
    • Go to Your_VM  > Overview and scroll down to Extensions + applications and you will see Microsoft.Insights.VMDiagnosticsSettings is now listed.
    • In the Application log on the VM you'll see lots of events with Id=0 and Source=AzureDiagnostics. There's some MsiInstaller events too. If you remove the Diagnostics extension these stop loggong.

    Aside: Viewing Diagnostic Data

    How do you view this data? There's a few ways but we're using Azure Storage Explorer.

    You can only install it on Win10 or 11. I built a Win11 desktop in Azure but it kept crashing so I ended up downloading an eval version and installing in VirtualBox and it was stable.

    It's easy to connect, just auth in the browser then wing it or proper steps here.

    Back to the VM tabs

    Let's go through each tab under Your_VM > Monitoring > Diagnostic settings and try and find the data in Storage Explorer. This table explains it well.

    1. On your VirtualBox VM, open Storage Explorer and go to Your_Subscription > Storage Accounts > Your_Storage_Account > Tables.
    2. In the Azure Portal go to Your_VM > Monitoring > Diagnostic settings
    Hint: To delete more than 100 events at a time in Storage Explorer, click the arrow next to Select All and select Select All Cached.

    Agent tab

    Here you can add/remove the agent (extension). If you select Collect Infrastructure Logs under Azure Diagnostic Agent Settings events are logged to the WADDiagnosticInfrastructureLogsTable table.

    To confirm this I unchecked Collect Infrastructure Logs then cleared the log in Storage Explorer (select all, delete) and bounced the VM. No events were logged. Then I checked Collect Infrastructure Logs and selected All for Log level and events were logged after a few minutes without even restarting.

    Interestingly, selecting Verbose log level resulted in the same event level and Id logged (Level=2, Id=64000), the messages were different though.

    One riddle solved, let's move on...

    Performance Counters tab

    By default there's a lot of counters added. Let's clean up the table and start fresh so you can see it.
    1. Remove all perf counters and save the settings.
    2. In Storage Explorer go to Your_Subscription > Storage Accounts > Your_Storage_Account > Tables and click on the WADPerformanceCountersTable table.
    3. Delete all events.
    4. On your VM add these counters and save settings:
      • Processor Information(_Total)\% Processor Time (Avg).
      • System\Processor Queue Length (Avg).
    5. Go to Your_VM > Monitoring > Metrics.
    6. Click the drop-down list under Metric Namespace, and you'll see there's now a Guest (classic) option under Custom, and the Metric drop-down shows the same counters from the Performance Counters tab.
    7. Wait a few minutes then go to Storage Explorer and click on the WADPerformanceCountersTable table and refresh.
    8. You should see events from the counters we selected coming in.
    I used the CpuStres tool to confirm the CPU was spiking.

    Note: While I was looking at the graphs I clicked on New alert rule thinking it might be easy to do an alert. I got this warning message:

    "Creating an alert rule from Metrics is not supported if the selection includes metrics from the Guest (classic) metric namespace. For guest metrics collected as custom metrics, select the metric from the Virtual Machine Guest namespace for Windows (learn more), or from the telegraf namespace for Linux (learn more). For guest metrics collected to a Log Analytics workspace, select the Log Analytics workspace as the target resource (learn more)."

    At this point we're getting some decent perf stuff. 😀

    Logs tab

    1. Uncheck all logs and save the settings.
    2. In Storage Explorer go to Your_Subscription > Storage Accounts > Your_Storage_Account > Tables and click on the WADWindowsEventLogsTable table.
    3. Delete all events.
    4. On your Azure VM collect only Application error and save settings.
    5. RDP to your VM and clear out the Application log.
    6. Follow this article to create a custom source and events.
    7. After a few minutes go to Storage Explorer and refresh.
    8. You should be collecting only error events.
    Now we're getting events. 😀

    I didn't test any of the other options on this tab.

    Event Tracing tab

    No testing performed.

    Crash Dumps tab

    No testing performed.

    Sinks tab

    This is where you can send diagnostic data to Azure Monitor or an Application Insights resource. As of 5/8/2024 the Azure Monitor option was in preview. I'm not testing Application Insights here, only Azure Monitor.

    Notice the Enable Azure Monitor box is greyed out with this message:

    "The Azure Monitor sink requires a managed identity. Click to configure a managed identity in Microsoft Entra ID for this VM."

    I don't know what this Identity stuff is yet but let's do what it says for now.

    1. Click on the message, click On and save settings.
    2. You might need to go out and back in to this page then you can click the Enable Azure Monitor check-box.
    3. I'm not sure what this does. The description says "Enabling this option will send diagnostic data collected by the Windows Diagnostics (WAD) agent to Azure Monitor, but it will not install the Azure Monitor agent itself on your VM". If you hover over the 🛈 symbol it says "Send metric data to Azure Monitor to analyze, chart, and query guest-level metrics side-by-side with Azure's resource-level metrics".
    One thing I noticed, if you go to Your_VM > Monitoring > Metrics and click on Metric Namespace you will now see Virtual Machine Guest under Custom and the same counters will be under Metric that you selected in Your_VM > Monitoring > Diagnostic settings > Performance Counters.

    So we're kind of collecting duplicate counters of the Guest (classic) namespace.

    If you disable Enable Azure Monitor in Sinks on the VM, you'll see it stops collecting data in the Metrics graph, re-enable it and off it goes again - at least we know that connection exists.

    Just to illustrate, under Metrics you can add the same counter - for example CPU % Used - for 3 different metric namespaces:

    • Virtual Machine Host - enabled by default on all Azure VMs.
    • Guest (classic) - enabled we when select Enable guest-level monitoring.
    • Virtual Machine Guest - enabled when we select Enable Azure Monitor in Sinks on the VM.
    Change Time range to 1 hour and Time granularity to 1 minute. If you've given it enough time to collect data, you'll see all 3 metrics are shown. If you do CPU spike tests you'll notice that the CPU counters from the OS perspective are higher than for the VM Host. This is probably similar to VMware where there's different perspectives on how a VM is performing - the inner and outer views as it were.

    Depending on the time range you select, you can get different results. Sometimes a metric would be missing or showing not collecting data. I don't know why. My guess is when you decide to send data to Azure Monitor you ditch using the Guest (classic) option.

    I'm mostly happy with diagnostics at this point. Let's continue...

    VM Insights (not Application Insights)

    Great overview here.

    To keep things clean, remove the Azure Diagnostic agent from the VM. You might also want to clean out tables in Storage Explorer.

    Agent stuff

    Note: The LA agent is being deprecated and not supported after August 2024. It's replace by Azure Monitoring Agent (AMA).

    When you enable VM Insights, these agents are installed:

    • Azure Monitoring Agent - Collects data from the virtual machine or Virtual Machine Scale Set and delivers it to the Log Analytics workspace.
    • Dependancy agent - This does a few things:
      • Collects data about process used in the Map feature.
      • Relies on the Azure Monitor Agent or LA agent to deliver data to Azure Monitor.
      • If you don't need the map feature, you don't need to install the Dependency agent.

    Data Collection Rules

    To enable VM Insights on a machine with Azure Monitor Agent, associate a VM insights data collection rule (DCR) with the agent. VM Insights creates a default data collection rule if one doesn't already exist. The data collection rule specifies the data to collect and the LA workspace to use:
    • Guest performance - this is perf data from the OS.
    • Processes and dependencies - process info used by the Map feature.
    • LA Workspace - workspace to store the data.

    Create LA workspace

    A prerequisite for this is an LA workspace.
    1.  On the Azure home page search for log and select Log Analytics workspaces under Services.
    2. Click Create with these settings:
      1. Subscription: Your_Subscription.
      2. Resource group: Your_ResGroup.
      3. Name: MyLA1.
      4. Region: Australia East.
    3. Click Create.

    Let's crack on.

    I'm following this guide so not all steps are noted.

    1. Go to Monitor > Insight > Virtual Machines > Overview.
    2. Note the Monitored and Not monitored tabs. "The Not monitored tab includes all machines that don't have VM insights enabled, even if the machines have Azure Monitor Agent or Log Analytics agent installed.". The Other onboarding options is interesting too.
    3. Click Enable on your VM under the Not monitored tab.
    4. On the Insights Onboarding page, select Enable.
    5. The doc is a bit old here. Notice the data collection rule and related settings is populated.
    6. Click on Create New.
    7. Give the DCR a name and select Enable processes and dependencies (Map) then select your LA workspace from earlier.
    8. Click Create.
    9. Click Configure.
    It will take a few minutes to complete but, what have we achieved here?

    A quick check-in

    I found at this point I was a bit lost. There's so much stuff in Azure and it's all over the place. There's often a few ways to get to the same spot and it can be different remembering how to get to spots you like. Let's do some memory-jogger stuff to get comfortable navigating this beast.

    A service is born

    The first thing you'll notice on your VM is that a service called Microsoft Dependency Agent has been installed. It's set to Manual start but whatevs for now.

    💡Note: The data shown in Your_VM > Overview > Monitoring (tab) > Performance and utilization is NOT created by Azure Monitor or what we just did. These metrics are collected for all new VMs without enabling anything.

    For these next sections I'm using this article as a guide.

    What agents have been installed?

    You can see general agent info here.
    1. Go to Your_VM > Overview > Properties (tab) > Extensions + applications (at bottom).

    Viewing Maps

    You can view the Map feature from:

    • Single VM - go to VM > Monitoring > Insights > Map.
    • Azure Monitor (all VMs) - Monitor > Insights > Virtual Machines > Map.

    The Map feature visualizes the VM dependencies by discovering running processes that have:
    • Active network connections between servers.
    • Inbound and outbound connection latency.
    • Ports across any TCP-connected architecture over a specified time range.
    1. In the same location as above, click on the Map tab. This shows a nice graphic of connections and processes, but it's the stuff on the right-hand side that's interesting. Click on each one to take a peek:
    • Properties
    • Log Events - This is data the VM has sent to Azure Monitor. The Event Type matches up with the tables under Monitor > Logs > Tables (blue + white square). If you click on one it'll take you to the Logs page. I am missing Perf in mine at the moment.
    • Alerts
    • Connections
    • Changes
    💡Note: If you RDP to the VM then get your computer's public ip address you will see it listed under Clients in Maps.

    Viewing performance

    I used this article for this bit.

    You can view perf stuff a few ways:

    • Single VM - go to VM > Monitoring > Insights > Performance.
      • You will see more counters here.
    • Azure Monitor (all VMs) - Monitor > Insights > Virtual Machines > Performance.
      • Not as many counters as single VM because it's a top x dealio.
      • Top N Charts, Aggregate Charts, Top N List are good to check out.
      • Click on Top N List and click on a VM and you properties to the right. There's quick links too.
    💡Note: To view the resource utilization by individual VM and see which machine is trending with highest utilization, select the Top N List tab. This shows the top 20 machines sorted by the most utilized by 95th percentile for the metric CPU Utilization %. To see more machines, select Load More. The results expand to show the top 500 machines. The list can't show more than 500 machines at a time.

    Performance diagnostics

    We've found even more monitoring stuff! Guide here. This article looks good too.

    This is a tool to identify and troubleshoot performance issues on your Azure virtual machine (VM) in one of two modes:
    • Continuous diagnostics (preview) collects data at five-second intervals and reports actionable insights about high resource usage every five minutes.
    • On-demand diagnostics helps you troubleshoot an ongoing performance issue with more in-depth data, insights, and recommendations based on data collected at a single point in time.

    Performance Diagnostics installs a VM extension that runs a diagnostics tool, called PerfInsights. It stores all insights and reports in a storage account, which you can configure for short data retention to minimize costs.

    💡Note: This has nothing to do with Insights or anything we've done here. It's a separate thing and can also be accessed from Virtual machines > Your_VM > Help > Performance diagnostics. The steps below were done a newly built VM with no agents installed.
    1. Go to Your_VM > Monitoring > Insights > Performance, look in any of the charts and you'll see an icon at the top-right next to the pin that looks like a computer screen with a magnifying glass over it. Click on it.
    2. You will bounce over to a new page, click on Enable performance diagnostics.
    3. I selected these:
      • Enable continuous diagnostics: Enabled.
      • Run on-demand diagnostics: Enabled. Choose Performance analysis.
      • Storage account name: Your_storage_account.
    4. Check the acknowledgement and click Apply.
    5. Doing this will kick off a scan/diagnostic then show results.
    6. If you go to Your_VM > Overview > Properties (tab) > Extensions + applications, you'll see a AzurePerformanceDiagnostics extension.
    💡Note: If you open Storage Explorer you will see some tables have been added:
    • AzPerfDiagFindingsTable
    • AzPerfDiagImpactedResourcesTable
    • AzPerfDiagRunsTable
    This thing is pretty cool.
    1. Go to Your_VM > Help > Performance diagnostics and you'll see some insights and recommendations. Because we selected continuous diagnostics, it will keep running and showing issues. This is not really something you'd want to keep running, only to troubleshooting.
    2. Click on Disable continuous diagnostics.
    3. So you can hop in here at anytime and run an on-demand diagnostic.
    I ran some tests of maxing out CPU and disk space and it showed up in the diagnostic 😀.


    💀 start here.












    Chart performance


    asfdasdf

    asdfasdf

    asdfasdf

    asdfasdf





    • Monitor > Insights > Virtual Machines will show data after 10 mins or so.
    • Go to Monitor > Logs and run this query. You should get a record back.

    VMComputer | summarize arg_max(TimeGenerated, *) by _ResourceId | project Computer, OperatingSystemFullName, DnsNames, Ipv4Addresses







    Log Analytics

    Delete workspace

    1. Go to Monitor > Insights > Log Analytics workspaces.
    2. Select your workspace then click on Overview > Delete.
    3. Select Delete the workspace permanently to avoid soft-delete state.

    Delete Data Collection Rules

    1. Go to Monitor > Settings > Data Collection Rules.
    2. Select and delete your rule.

    Questions

    • What is VM > Operations > Health Monitoring?
    • Read more on Azure Storage accounts.
    • What is Monitor > Settings > Diagnostic settings?
    • What is VM > Help > Performance diagnostics?
    • What is the WADMetricsExtensionLogsTable table in Storage Explorer. Some good stuff in there.

    Random Notes

    The data platform stores the collected monitoring data. Azure Monitor's core data platform has stores for metrics, logs, traces, and changes.

    A common way to route monitoring data to other non-Microsoft tools is using Event hubs.

    To implement Microsoft Sentinel, you need a Log Analytics workspace.

    Full-stack monitoring is the term for a monitoring strategy that takes a complete approach to monitoring, triaging, and diagnosing application, infrastructure, and security issues.

    AzMon Pic

    This is a great image. Azure Monitor encompasses a lot of tools.

entry.title: Sourdough
entry.content:
Makes 1 loaf. Takes 2 days. Covers white and wholemeal versions. 🔒

This is a nice standard loaf, not too much twang. The white loaf is solid but I have not done the wholemeal loaf in the big tin yet.

Golden rule: To get good results, it's all about time + temperature.

If it's cold use the humidicrib with a damp sponge and set temp to 23 C.

Kit

  • Big silver bowl (double loaf) or usual silver bowl (single loaf).
  • Fork.
  • Big loaf tins (white loaf).
  • Black tin (wholemeal loaf).
  • Usual bits.

Ingredients

Ingredient White 72% hyd Wholemeal 75% hyd
Starter 150 - 160 gm 110 - 120 gm
Yeast 1/2 tsp
 1/2 tsp
Water 420 gm
 330 gm
White flour 608 gm
 228 gm
Wholemeal flour NA 228 gm
Salt 12 gm
 12 gm

Method - Day 1

Prepare starter.

Method - Day 2

  1. Add starter to bowl.
  2. Warm water to 35 C and add to bowl (1 min in microwave).
  3. Add yeast to bowl.
  4. Chop up and mix fork.
  5. Add flours, salt, seeds (if using) and mix until no dry spots.
  6. Spray water on top, rest 1 hour.
  7. Take out of bowl, do ~12 folds and some slap-n-fold.
  8. Spray water on top, back in bowl, rest 2 hours.
  9. Take out of bowl and do ~6 folds, then some slap-n-fold.
  10. Spray water on top, back in bowl, rest 2 hours.
  11. Grease up the loaf tin.
  12. Flour bench with white flour and take out of bowl.
  13. Stretch it out in a long rectangle and flatten with fingers. Make sure it's the width of the tin.
  14. Roll it up towards you and seal bottom.
  15. Put in loaf tin.
  16. Cover and rest 2 hours.
  17. It should rise to roughly 2 cm from top of pan. Don't worry it'll pop in the oven.
  18. Pre-heat oven 20 mins.
  19. Spray water on top, slash it and add seeds and spray water again.
  20. Bake with steam following method below.
  21. Leave overnight to make slicing up easier.

Bake time

  • 15 mins @ 250 C
  • 15 mins @ 200 C
  • 30 mins @ 200 C (15 mins for wholemeal)

Notes

7/8/2024

Did wholemeal loaf. Baked 45 mins. Used 158 gm starter. It was a bit too sour, next time follow ingredients quantity. Didn't pop a whole lot in the oven.

27/7/2024

Did a double batch of white loaf. Baked same time + temp, turned out fine. Use big silver bowl for mixing 'coz she's a whopper. 

9/7/2024

Did white recipe using 430 gm water and 68 gm wholemeal and 540 gm while (608 gm total). Turned out fine.

Question: Can you get same result using 1/4 tsp yeast instead of 1/2?

If you cover and leave out overnight it's easier to slice the next day.

entry.title: Ciabatta
entry.content:
Makes 2. Takes 2 days. 🔒

It's typically ready by 5 pm and uses a poolish. If you need the loaves ready earlier, do the poolish early in the morning, then do Day 2 steps 1-2 at night then step 4 is to leave it overnight - I haven't tested this though.

Kit

  • 2 scrapers.
  • Metal bowl.

Ingredients

  • 400 gm water.
  • 500 gm flour.
  • 1 gm yeast (1/4 tsp).
  • 7 gm salt.

Method

Day 1 - Make poolish

Take this from ingredients above.
  1. Warm 182 gm water to 35 C, add to bowl.
  2. Add all the yeast to bowl. Mix and leave 10 mins to dissolve.
  3. Add 182 gm flour to bowl and mix well.
  4. Cover and leave overnight.

Day 2

  1. Warm remaining water (218 gm) to 35 C and add to poolish. Stir it in.
  2. Add remaining flour (318 gm)
  3. Add salt (7 gm) and mix well.
  4. Rest 3 hours or leave overnight if you need loaves earlier.
  5. On bench, slap-n-fold then rest 1 hour (shorten these times if necessary).
  6. Repeat step 5 two more times.
  7. Use big oven tray and flour couche well.
  8. Flour bench well and tip out dough.
  9. Flour top well and shape into square.
  10. Cut in half and push each bit to the side to separate.
  11. Put on couche. Tip: Use two scrapers either side to lift it.
  12. Rest 30 mins. Put baking stone on middle rack and crank oven to 250 C.
  13. Critical bit: you need to flip them over so you don't get flour-creases on the bottom.
  14. Take couche off tray. Make sure they aren't sticking and flip them over being careful not to crease them underneath.
  15. Take baking stone out of oven and put on the upturned tray. Using two scrapers, scoop up each one at both ends and put on stone, don't stretch it, you'll lose volume.
  16. Straighten them up and put in oven.
  17. Bake with steam 20 mins @ 250 C.

Notes

3/8/2024

Tried cutting into thirds so I can use baguette peels. It was pretty awkward as they were nearly as big as the peels. Because they are so floppy they had creases underneath again, not too bad though. Don't know if this was any easier. They just fit on the baking stone, you could try reduce the recipe by 25%

20/1/2024

These are awesome. Watch the use of wholemeal flour to dust, it might impact flavour. If going public use white only.

entry.title: Cooking general tips
entry.content:
Cooking

Recipes to try


Rice absorption

Brown

1 cup brown rice needs 2 cups water. Takes about 5 mins to get to a boil and 25 mins to cook. Total weight is 490 gm. You'll get 3 meals out of it (163 gm each).

White

1 cup white rice needs 1.5 cups water. Takes about 5 mins to get to a boil and ~15 mins to cook.

Conversions

  • 1/4 tsp yeast = 1 gm
  • 1/2 tsp yeast = 2 gm
  • 1/2 tsp salt = 3 gm
  • 1 tsp salt = 6 gm
  • 1 Tbsp olive oil = 14 gm

Weight / Volume

  • 1.4 ltr bowl when empty = 825 gm
  • 2.4 ltr bowl when empty = 1035 gm
  • 3.8 ltr bowl when empty = 1543 gm
  • 1 cup bread crumbs = 4 slices

Hydration

To get bread hydration:

liquid / flour x 100

I.e. If a recipe has 170gm water and 225 flour:

170 / 225 x 100 = 75% hydration

Get percentage of a number

To get the percentage of a number:

% x fixed_number / 100

I.e. To get 10% of 5000:

10 x 4194172 / 100 = 500

Temperature

Softened butter 18-21 C.

Eggs

Boil the googy

  • Put eggs in pan, add water and bring to boil (takes 6-7 mins).
  • When boiling turn off gas and leave 3-4 mins.
If you steep a 60 gm egg for 4 mins it will be slightly runny. Good for adding to pastas.

entry.title: Slab
entry.content:
Kit

  • Big pot (yes that one).
  • Mid-size pot.
  • White bowl to drain pasta.

Ingredients

  • 1 large onion.
  • 1 pack bacon.
  • 800 gm tomatoes.
  • 400 gm pasta.
  • 20 gm butter.
  • Salt, pepper.
  • 4 pinches of sugar.
  • 1 Tbsp basil.
  • Cheese in sauce (150 gm fat boy, 100 gm skinny boy).
  • Cheese on top (350 gm fat boy, 200 gm skinny boy).

Method

Until we get a bigger pot to do pasta in, do it this way.
  1. Chop bacon, onion and butter into large pieces and add to smaller pot.
  2. Add tomato and rinse can(s) and bring to boil. Keep the can.
  3. Kick off pasta water in large pot.
  4. Pre-heat oven to 180 C.
  5. Remove from heat. Add salt, pepper, butter and basil simmer 20 mins.
  6. Keep aside 100 gm uncooked pasta, add rest to big pot. Cook during the 20 mins.
  7. Drain pasta water into bowl.
  8. Add sauce to big pot.
  9. Put can on scale and pour ~200 gm pasta water into it.
  10. Add all contents to big pot and mix.
  11. Add to dish and add cheese on top.
  12. Bake 30 mins @ 180 C.

entry.title: Burger bun
entry.content:
Makes 8 buns. Takes 2 days. Start 9 am, ready by 4 pm.

Bits

  • Blue lid bowl
  • Round pizza tray
  • Humidicrib (winter)

Ingredients

Tangzhong

  • 25 gm flour
  • 120 water

Dough

  • 200 gm milk
  • 7 gm yeast
  • 1 egg
  • 30 gm milk powder
  • 7 gm salt
  • 360 gm flour
  • 45 gm unsalted butter

Method

Day 1

  • Make tangzhong and put in bowl, fridge overnight.

Day 2

Rest times are usually 2 hours @ 21 C.
  • Room temp tangzhong and butter. Put both in humidicrib. Takes ~1 hour.
  • Warm milk to 35 C, add to bowl.
  • Add egg and yeast, stir with fork to dissolve.
  • Add flour, salt, and milk powder and mix well.
  • On bench, knead until smooth.
  • Add butter and knead until combined.
  • Add tangzhong and knead until combined.
  • By the end it's very sticky. Wet hands and shape into ball, back in bowl until doubled.
  • Cut into 8 pcs (~100 gm each), shape into ball and put aside.
  • Flour the balls well all over.
  • Flatten again by hand to make them wider and put on tray.
  • Tray use:
    • Round tray - just butter it, it fits 8 balls nicely and they don't stick.
    • Big rectangle tray - line it and stagger like this:
⬤    ⬤    ⬤
    ⬤    ⬤
⬤    ⬤    ⬤
  • Rest until doubled.
  • If adding seeds, spray with water before and after so they stick.
  • Bake with steam 15 mins @ 180 C.
  • Optional - after baking, wrap in cloth to keep soft.

Notes

24/4/2024

These turned out good. I did ~98 gm buns and flattened them as much as possible, after baking they were the size of a big mac .

entry.title: Reg Examples
entry.content:
Some reg.exe examples.

To run on remote computer, prefix with \\COMPUTER.

REG QUERY

Get subkeys and values

reg query "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Network Associates\ePolicy Orchestrator"

Get data from a value

reg query "\\COMPUTER\HKLM\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Network Associates\ePolicy Orchestrator" /v InstallFolder

REG ADD

Disable taskbar thumbnails

It's either one or both of these, (both DWORD 32-bit). Need to reboot.

This delays the hover in seconds.

reg add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Advanced /v ExtendedUIHoverTime /t REG_DWORD /d 600000 /f

Set NumThumbnails = 0.

reg add HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Taskband /v NumThumbnails /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f 

Disable Windows Defender

reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows Defender"

reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows Defender" /v DisableAntiSpyware /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f

reg add HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\mpssvc /v Start /t REG_DWORD /d 4 /f

Disable UAC

reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\policies\system /v EnableLUA /t REG_DWORD /d 0

entry.title: Amnesia
entry.content:
• Apps
  • Config Manager
  • Cooking
  • Disable User Account Control
  • Excel
  • Percentages
  • SCOM
  • Software registry key
  • VSCode

Apps

Metronome

As of October 2023, Natural Metronome by Single Minded Productions works well.

Sportractive

Free running app for mobile that tracks distance.

Make ISOs

Google cdburnerxp or https://cdburnerxp.se/en/home (working April 2017)

Make a bootable USB key or wipe it:

Google rufus usb or https://rufus.akeo.ie/ (working July 2017)

Config Manager

  • The tool to view logs is CMTrace.exe and it's in C:\Windows and C:\Windows\CCM.
  • A useful log for agent problems is C:\Windows\CCM\Logs\CcmExec.log

Disable User Account Control

  1. Control Panel.
  2. Security and Maintenance.
  3. Change User Account Control settings.
  4. Set to Never Notify.

Excel

Shortcuts

Task Shortcut
Delete row Ctrl - (minus)
Insert row Alt + I + R
Insert multiple rows Select rows then Alt + I + R
Insert column Alt + I + C
Insert multiple columns Select rows then Alt + I + C
Select row Shift + Spacebar
Filter  Ctrl + Shift + L
Switch worksheets Ctrl + Pg Up / Pg Down
Insert worksheet Shift + F11
Delete worksheet Alt, H, D, S

Percentages

Get percentage of a number

If you want to get a percentage of a fixed number:

% x fixed_number / 100

So to get 10% of 5000 it's:

10 x 4194172 / 100 = 500

Get percentage of 2 numbers

There's a few ways to do this. Try both if the number doesn't look right. If you're baking, sometimes you need to get the total of something first; i.e. using two flours you'd add them together to get total flour then use below calculation to get individual percentages of each. Make sense? 🤕

What percentage is 3000 of 5000?

3000 / 5000 * 100 = 60%

What percentage is 1 of 4426?

(4426 - 1) / 4426 * 100 = 99.9%

SCOM

Links

  • System.OleDbProbe (Query SQL without a script - good for simple yes/no things)
    • Query a database
    • This helped with ConnectionString bit
  • On-demand monitors
  • On-demand monitors 2
  • OpsMgr++
  • Random stuff but good

What happens to a service monitor on a computer that doesn't have the service installed?

It won't alert with it not being installed but Health Explorer will show the service as being monitored which is misleading. I have also seen alerts generated saying the service wasn't running so keep it simple and only monitor services that are actually installed.

Will my group override work?

My CMDB groups contain 3 main classes:
  • Microsoft.Windows.Computer
  • Microsoft.Windows.Cluster
  • Microsoft.SystemCenter.HealthServiceWatcher

For the rules and monitors I want enabled, these work great but there's some classes that don't inherit nicely so the override won't work. This section contains a list of classes where I have confirmed if the override works or not when it targets the group.

Class Comment
Microsoft.SystemCenter.Agent Overrides work if group contains Microsoft.Windows.Computer class.
Microsoft.SystemCenter.HealthService
 Overrides work if group contains Microsoft.Windows.Computer class.

Override inheritance (class, group, object)

What happens if you have an override that targets a class, group and object? This is from Microsoft:

"Overrides that apply to a class are applied first, then overrides that apply to a group, and finally overrides that apply to a specific object."

Full article here.

Rule-generated alerts

When you disable a rule that generates alerts it will not close active alerts generated by that rule. You need to close them manually.

Overrides targeting groups in sealed MPs

These don't work because of the  ContextInstance attribute. You will get an error when you try to seal the mp.

Do overrides targeting a group with sub-groups work?

Yes. For example, if I have a root group called Test Root Group and it contains a sub-group called Test Sub Group that contains objects that the rule/monitor targets, an override targeting Test Root Group does "flow on" to objects in the sub-groups. I tested this successfully with the "High cpu" alert by adding a Windows Computer object to Test Sub Group.

Kick off a discovery on an agent without admin rights

I've often had the need to restart the HealthService on an agent to kick off discoveries but not had admin rights on the server. If you go to Operations Manager > Agent Details > Agents By Version there's 2 tasks that target the Health Service:

  • Reload Configuration
  • Flush Health Service State and Cache

I've tested both of these and not completely sure what each does but I've had more luck with Flush Health Service State and Cache so use that.

What is the default behaviour for agent and gateway failover?

Apparently agents failover to another MS automatically but gateways need to be configured manually.

Send parameters into SCOM tasks

When you send parameters into a SCOM task, it is a  string type. This will mess you up if you are sending in a comma separated list as a parameter and you want to run commands against each one. Remember, it's not an array. If you need to test it, run $ParamVariable.gettype() in the task.

Management servers in maintenance mode

From what I've seen in SCOM 2016, this is what happens if all mgmt servers are in maintenance mode:

  • Monitoring pretty much stops
  • The most recent alert is back when MM started
  • Mgmt servers and agents can't exit out of maintenance mode

Registry discovery attributes

If you make a registry discovery you need to put values in PathType and AttributeType and I can never remember them. Kev's Class.And.Discovery.Registry.* mps explain them all.

Software registry key

This is the key if you need to find software info:

HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall

VSCode

Shortcuts

Task Shortcut
Bookmark: Jump next Ctrl + Alt + L
Bookmark: Toggle Ctrl + Alt + K
Command palette F1 / Ctrl + Shift + P
Copy line Shift + Alt + 🠉 🠋
Delete line Ctrl + Shift + K
Open settings Ctrl + ,
Show/hide sidebar Ctrl + B
Word wrap Alt + Z

Search and replace in selection

  1. Select the text you want to replace.
  2. Ctrl + H.
  3. Paste your new text.
  4. Drag over the section you want to replace.
  5. Alt + L.
  6. Ctrl + Alt + Enter.

Tweaks

Settings.json

To open settings.json for your user account, press F1 and search for settings.json and select Preferences: Open User Settings (JSON).

The tweaks I like are listed here, just dump this into settings.json.

{
  "telemetry.enableCrashReporter": false,
  "telemetry.enableTelemetry": false,
  "workbench.enableExperiments": false,
  "git.enableSmartCommit": true,
  "git.confirmSync": false,
  "git.autofetch": true,
  "editor.minimap.enabled": false,
  "files.associations": {
    "*.mpx": "xml"
  },
  "workbench.startupEditor": "none",
  "workbench.colorTheme": "Visual Studio Dark",
  "highlight-matching-tag.styles": {
    "opening": {
      "name": {
        "highlight": "orange"
      }
    }
  },
  "js/ts.implicitProjectConfig.checkJs": true,
  "editor.occurrencesHighlight": false,
  "json.schemas": [],
  "workbench.colorCustomizations": { // This lets you set the tab border colour.
    "tab.activeBorder": "#ffee00", // Tab colour.
    "tab.unfocusedActiveBorder": "#000000" //Don't know what this does.
}
}

Disable grey background highlight when clicking on a word

This is already covered in settings.json above.
  1. Press F1.
  2. Type in Open Settings (UI) and select it.
  3. Search for Occurrences Highlight.
  4. Under Editor: Occurrences Highlight untick Controls whether the editor should highlight semantic symbol occurrences.

Change XML highlight tag colour

This is already in settings.json under Tweaks but showing here in case you ever need to add manually. Update orange to whatever colour you want.

Just add this to settings.json.

"highlight-matching-tag.styles": {
"opening": {
"name": {
"highlight": "orange"
}}}

Extensions

Some useful extensions:
  • Microsoft PowerShell
  • Bookmarks - Alessandro Fragnani
  • Highlight Matching Tag - vincaslt
  • highlight-words - Richard Bondi
  • XML Tools - Josh Johnson

entry.title: Install SCOM 2016 (minimal admin access)
entry.content:
This will install SCOM 2016 in a lab without giving all accounts admin access.

Note: The SQL eval expires so you will need to re-build MS1 each time. The SQL services and SSMS won't start and event 17051 is in the Application log. You can just keep re-arming DC1.

Servers

Name Description
DC1.lab.com Domain controller
MS1.lab.com SQL + SCOM 2016

Accounts

Name Description
om-install Used to install/maintain SQL & SCOM. Access removed post install.
om-msa Mgmt server action account. Local admin on mgmt server.
om-das Data access/Config account. Local admin on mgmt server.
om-rdr Data reader account. Member of 'Domain Users' only.
om-wrt Data writer account. Member of 'Domain Users' only.
om-admin SCOM Admin only. Not local server admin.
sql-srv Runs all SQL services.

Groups

Name Description
SRV-Admins Local server administrators.
OM-Admins SCOM Admin group. Added post install.
SQL-Admins SQL Admin group. Added during install.

Install DC1

  1. Rename the computer.
  2. Add the IP address (VBox nic set to NAT). Do not use on work networks.
  3. Install Virtualbox guest additions and reboot.
  4. Add the DNS and AD DC roles and run dcpromo.
  5. When computer has 180-day Microsoft license set VBox nic type to Host-only Adapter.

Disable firewall + screen saver

netsh advfirewall set allprofiles state off

Go to Control Panel > Power Options > High performance > Change plan settings > Never for both.

Disable Windows Defender

reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows Defender"

reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Windows Defender" /v DisableAntiSpyware /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f

reg add HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\mpssvc /v Start /t REG_DWORD /d 4 /f

Disable UAC

reg add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\policies\system /v EnableLUA /t REG_DWORD /d 0

Setup accounts

  1. When DC1 is functional run these:
::START

::Create OU
dsadd ou "ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com"

::Create users
dsadd user cn=om-install,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -samid om-install -upn om-install@lab.com -fn om-install -display om-install -desc "SCOM Install Account" -pwd P@ssword -pwdneverexpires yes -disabled no

dsadd user cn=om-msa,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -samid om-msa -upn om-msa@lab.com -fn om-msa -display om-msa -desc "SCOM Mgmt Server Action Account" -pwd P@ssword -pwdneverexpires yes -disabled no

dsadd user cn=om-das,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -samid om-das -upn om-das@lab.com -fn om-das -display om-das -desc "SCOM Data Access/Config Account" -pwd P@ssword -pwdneverexpires yes -disabled no

dsadd user cn=om-rdr,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -samid om-rdr -upn om-rdr@lab.com -fn om-rdr -display om-rdr -desc "SCOM Reader Account" -pwd P@ssword -pwdneverexpires yes -disabled no

dsadd user cn=om-wrt,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -samid om-wrt -upn om-wrt@lab.com -fn om-wrt -display om-wrt -desc "SCOM Writer Account" -pwd P@ssword -pwdneverexpires yes -disabled no

dsadd user cn=om-admin,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -samid om-admin -upn om-admin@lab.com -fn om-admin -display om-admin -desc "SCOM Admin Account" -pwd P@ssword -pwdneverexpires yes -disabled no

dsadd user cn=sql-srv,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -samid sql-srv -upn sql-srv@lab.com -fn sql-srv -display sql-srv -desc "SQL Server Account" -pwd P@ssword -pwdneverexpires yes -disabled no

::Create groups and add users
dsadd group cn=SRV-Admins,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -desc "Local Server Administrators Group"  -members "CN=om-install,OU=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com" "CN=om-msa,OU=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com" "CN=om-das,OU=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com"

dsadd group cn=OM-Admins,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -desc "SCOM Administrators Group"  -members "CN=om-install,OU=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com" "CN=om-msa,OU=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com" "CN=om-das,OU=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com" "CN=om-admin,OU=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com"

dsadd group cn=SQL-Admins,ou=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com -desc "SQL Administrators Group" -members "CN=sql-srv,OU=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com" "CN=om-install,OU=Objects,DC=lab,DC=com"

::END

Install MS1

  1. Rename the computer.
  2. Add the IP address (VBox nic set to NAT). Do not use on work networks.
  3. Install Virtualbox guest additions and reboot.
  4. When computer has 180-day Microsoft license set VBox nic type to Host-only Adapter.
  5. Add to domain.
  6. Log in as lab\administrator.

Disable firewall + screen saver

  1. Run this:
netsh advfirewall set allprofiles state off

Disable screen saver

Control Panel > Power Options > High performance > Change plan settings > Never for both.

Disable UAC

REG ADD HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\policies\system /v EnableLUA /t REG_DWORD /d 0

Setup local groups

  1. Log in as lab\administrator and run this then logoff:
net localgroup administrators /add lab\SRV-Admins
net localgroup "Remote Desktop Users" /add lab\om-admin

The last line allows lab\om-admin rdp to MS1.lab.com.

Install SQL 2014

Install .NET pre-reqs

  1. Log in to MS1.lab.com as lab\om-install
  2. Mount the Windows server ISO.
  3. Open admin Powershell and run this command. This also fulfils the requirement to have .dotnet installed for the SQL install.
Add-WindowsFeature NET-WCF-HTTP-Activation45,Web-Static-Content,Web-Default-Doc,Web-Dir-Browsing,Web-Http-Errors,Web-Http-Logging,Web-Request-Monitor,Web-Filtering,Web-Stat-Compression,Web-Mgmt-Console,Web-Metabase,Web-Asp-Net,Web-Windows-Auth –Restart -Source D:\sources\sxs

Install SQL 2014

  1. If you are re-using a server make sure the .NET Framework 3.5 feature is installed otherwise the SQL pre-reqs fail.
  2. Copy SQL ISO from Passport drive to C:\temp. It's in Backup\Anth\Work\DXC\Apps\SQL\2014\SQLServer2014SP2-FullSlipstream-x64-ENU.iso 
  3. Run C:\temp\setup.exe.
  4. Click on Installation and choose stand-alone install.
Use defaults unless specified.
  • Add these features:
    • Database Engine Services
    • Full-Text and Semantic Extractions For Search
    • Reporting Services - Native
    • Management Tools - Complete
  • If using a named instance, type the name in Named Instance and Instance ID or it will error. I usually call it SCOMINST.
  • Use sql-srv for these services & set them all to auto start:
    • SQL Server Agent
    • SQL Server Database Engine
    • SQL Server Reporting Services
Apparently collation no longer matters but I still set it to SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CI_AS.
  • Add the SQL-Admins group at the SQL Administrators prompt.
  • Leave Reporting Services Native Mode as Install and configure.
  • Kick off the install then restart when done.

Install SCOM 2016

  1. Log in to MS1.lab.com as lab\om-install
  2. Install SQLSysClrTypes_SQL2012.msi (yes you need this) then ReportViewer.msi. These are in C:\Data\SCOM\Apps.
  3. Copy SC2016_SCOM_EN.EXE to C:\temp, extract it and launch the install.
  4. Select all install options.
  5. Enter MG name.
  6. Enter SQL name and instance.
  7. Use the following service accounts:
    • Msaa -  lab\om-msa
    • Das - lab\om-das
    • Reader - lab\om-rdr
    • Writer - lab\om-wrt
  • Open the console when finished.
  • Add lab\OM-Admins to Operations Manager Administrators and remove BUILTIN\Administrators.

Notes

The install was successful and I didn't get any errors. I would have thought that om-rdr & om-wrt accounts would need to be in local admin group.

entry.title: Sourdough starter
entry.content:
General notes on making and maintaining a sourdough starter.

Making

If making a new starter, follow Jack process. It's important to maintain the temperature or it won't work. When it's cold use the humidicrib (set to 23 C). Always use 35 C water.

Maintenance

If you haven't used it for 2+ weeks, feed it 25 gm water & flour at the start of the day. This will resuscitate it a bit. At the end of the day, you can either discard it (if it's looking particularly weak) or top up with more water/flour to get required starter volume ready for using the next day. The golden rule is: if the starter isn't airy it will affect the rise.

Always seal the lid when storing. I lost a few starters in the beginning and can only blame it on oxygen. As soon as I started sealing them they survived.

entry.title: Basketball training
entry.content:
Rules 💀 

If you fuck around you run a lap
If fucking around continues team runs a lap

Warm up - 5 mins

If you don't touch the paint or call out lap number you start again.
  • Start on sideline
  • Jog up and touch paint
  • Sprint back and touch paint
  • Call out number
  • Do 5 times

Dribbling - 5 mins

Now we incorporate dribbling.

  • Similar to above
  • Walk first half
  • Run second half
  • Use both hands, do crossovers, mix it up

Passing - 10 mins

Cover the basic passes. Remember foot work.

Pair up and throw to each other trying different passes, short and long distance.
  • Chest pass
  • Bounce pass
  • Dominant hand
  • Weak hand

Keepings off - 15 mins

Need groups of 3 for this. 2 players on end pass to each other, player in middle tries to get ball.

Explain defense

  • When you're 1:1 with a player, hands up and swipe up or to the side
  • Don't swipe down, it increases chances of hitting an arm and fouling the player

Explain pivoting

Pivoting is more of an offence thing. It's used mostly in attack but also trying to get ball out of defense.
  • 1 foot stays on the ground, the heel can come up.
  • The other foot can move
  • Cover front and reverse pivot

Finding space

This is a fluid version of above. Just work in the arc and tie it together. No shooting.
  • Try and read the play
  • Help your team mate by finding space and running into it
  • Call for the ball with voice and body

Shooting - 5 mins

Cover free throws and lay ups.
  • Do running lay ups and close range
  • Teach proper free throw technique

Practice Game - 20 mins

Put all above into practice. Blow whistle when they mess up.

Game Day Reminders

  • Good luck
  • No subs watch the fouls
  • Keep possession of the ball
  • Run to help team mates
  • Call with voice and body
  • Fast passes, no blind stuff

entry.title: DIY
entry.content:
Keep all notes on DIY here.

Concrete repair

May 2024.

I'm trying to get a solid process for repairing concrete to make it skate-able.

This worked well on a decent size hole. I had all the gear.

  • Scrub clean with water and brush.
  • Rinse with water, leave it damp.
  • Mix Dunlop grout with Dunlop primer (pics below). Ratio on box is 1500 gm powder to 315 gm water/primer so the liquid is 21% of the powder.
  • I used 300 gm powder 63 primer (no water dilution). Mix well.
  • Use paint brush to paint white glue onto surface.
  • Fill crack/holes and smooth out with scraper.

Try these products is if above doesn't work, use same process though:
  • Clean with Hydrochloric acid.
  • Use Concremate instead of grout.

Replace triple switch light in hallway

April 2024.

The hallway light button was making buzzing noises. I bought a DETA White Triple Switch from Bunnings for $16. Replacing was easy, just put wires in same spot but do a thorough check that they match up first.

Fix tiles on porch

March 2024.

For the tiles I used this:

For the grout I used the same primer and grout that I used for the shower. If you want to use the primer (think it gives a better bond) it's a 1:1 ratio to mix with water. So if you need 60gm water it's 30gm water and 30gm primer.

Shower repair

Did a full repair on this bastard September 2023.

Grout

Base paint

The silicone was crap and made more mess to clean up.

Silicon

I removed all old silicon. The silicone remove was crap, don't use again.

Cleaned out old silicon from mixer section. The circular tube in the pic below unscrews. Below that, we want to replace the cartridge, the copper thing also unscrews, you'll need a shifter.

Used these:

Replacement mixer thing

Guitar

Section 2
